Allison Rose, a Senior Correspondent and Critic at FlickDirect, is a dynamic presence in the entertainment industry with a communications degree from Hofstra University. She brings her film expertise to KRMS News/Talk 97.5 FM and broadcast television, and is recognized as a Tomatometer-Approved Critic. Her role as an adept event moderator in various entertainment industry forums underscores her versatility. Her affiliations with SEFCA, the Florida Film Critics Circle, and the Online Film Critics Society highlight her as an influential figure in film criticism and media.

The first type enjoys his broad comedies ‚Äì the crasser the better, the more Kevin James and Rob Schneider on screen, the better. If Sandler is off in some sunny location, goofing around with his mates and calls it a movie, woo!  The second type of Sandler fan is extremely selective. They think his early stand-up work is good, they might even cop to liking Happy Gilmore (but maybe wouldn‚Äôt if they saw it again). But what they really like is when Sandler is in other people‚Äôs movies. The point is, for the second type of Sandler fans, when he‚Äôs in other people‚Äôs movies, and when he has little involvement in the creative development of those films, that‚Äôs when he‚Äôs at his best. Which makes the Sandler you see in Uncut Gems a marriage of the two camps. It‚Äôs a very Sandler performance ‚Äì intense, loud and big. But in a movie that is so far from a typical Sandler movie.  Uncut Gems is directed by Josh and Benny Safdie, indie filmmakers with a track record for challenging thrillers. The Safdies don‚Äôt make easy-to-watch, forgettable comedies, they make high-stakes, madcap films that captivate and linger. Much like the hunk of rock at the centre of Uncut Gems, a thousand-plus carat of black opal which hypnotises, described by Sandler‚Äôs character Howard as ‚Äúyou can see the whole universe in there‚Äù. Howard is a dealer in Manhattan‚Äôs diamond district, a man with a lot of complications in his life, all of which he‚Äôs brought on himself. A problem gambler being chased by his loan shark‚Äôs (Eric Bogosian) goons, he‚Äôs also juggling between a wife (Idina Menzel) who‚Äôs about to leave him and a girlfriend (Julia Fox) whose apartment he‚Äôs paying for. When the black opal, wrapped inside a fish, shows up, Howard is mesmerised by its beauty but also by how it‚Äôs going to get him out of debt. So, he probably shouldn‚Äôt agree, however reluctantly, to lend it out to legendary NBA player Kevin Garnett (playing himself) for good luck. Your first type of Sandler fan might be surprised by the kind of movie they‚Äôve signed up to with Uncut Gems, but hopefully they‚Äôll stick around because the propulsive thrills are so visceral, it‚Äôs an experience they won‚Äôt find in Grown Ups 3 (god help us if that actually eventuates).  Uncut Gems is a sensational movie ‚Äì from the first minute to the end, it won‚Äôt let up. There is no reprieve from the tension that‚Äôs been stretched so tight you‚Äôre certain it‚Äôs going to snap. But the Safdies are so adept at maintaining that anxiety, you have to just sit back and marvel. Sandler is on excellent form and gives a performance with so much momentum, chaos and power, it once again begs why he doesn‚Äôt do this kind of thing more often.  Anchored around that key Sandler performance, Uncut Gems works on every level ‚Äì the dazzling script, the cinematography with its gritty aesthetic and the production design which drops the audience into this gauche world. But the thing that elevates it above all else is the frenetic energy that infuses every scene, yet calibrated so perfectly so that it stays, barely, on the right side of frustrating. There‚Äôs nothing more thrilling than that. The film Civil War is an anxiety-inducing experience from start to finish ‚Äì but one scene in particular will likely stay with you long after the credits roll. A major film up for five awards at this year‚Äôs Oscars has been accused of ‚Äúline by line‚Äù plagiarism in an explosive new report published on the eve of the event.

A self-destructive gambling addict who is swiftly spiralling out of control is the subject of the Safdie brothers‚Äô latest film, Uncut Gems. The film is an intense crime thriller driven by a terrific performance by Adam Sandler. The protagonist is Howard Ratner (Sandler), a jeweller who is addicted to sports gambling and owes money to his loan shark brother-in-law, Arno (Eric Bogosian).  His personal life isn‚Äôt faring any better than his financial situation. His estranged wife, Dinah (Idina Menzel), wants a divorce, although the couple are keeping up appearances for the sake of their children. And, he is shacking up with his mistress and jewellery store employee, Julia (Julia Fox). Howard hopes his luck will turn with the auction and sale of a rare gemstone he has acquired and that Basketball player Kevin Garnett (playing himself) has taken a shine to. But things, as you would expect, don‚Äôt go quite according to plan. With each misstep, he falls deeper into trouble. Every time the debt collectors come calling, he finds himself in hot water(s). You spend nearly two hours squirming at Howard‚Äôs actions, choices, and dishonesties, wondering if he will manage to redeem himself or will instead fall prey to his own vices.  But even though he is a thoroughly unlikable character, you eventually get to the point where you still find yourself hoping he wins. If for no other reason, than to give the viewer a respite from the constant stress of the situation. Between the frenetic pacing, non-stop chattering and yelling, and chaotic predicament, the tension rarely lets up. That might be why watching Uncut Gems isn‚Äôt exactly an enjoyable experience ‚Äì it‚Äôs stressful and hectic and anxiety-provoking. But, that doesn‚Äôt take away from the fact that the Safdies have created a drama that is downright fascinating. The setting, too, is interesting, although perhaps delving a little deeper into the harsh backdrop might have made it even more intriguing.  A slight misstep also emerges in the form of the intrusive soundtrack which, it‚Äôs fairly obvious, was meant to be visceral, but is instead often jarring, especially in the initial sequence. The credit for carrying the film goes entirely to Adam Sandler who is surprisingly terrific in his role as a hustling sleazeball. It really is a shame that the actor didn‚Äôt get an Oscar nod, and whether you have liked his previous works or not, chances are you will walk out of Uncut Gems impressed by his performance while simultaneously dreading and looking forward to the terrible movie he promised to make if he was snubbed by the Academy.

I never have been a fan of Adam Sandler movies. The pictures he makes often are vulgar and mean, and some are simply terrible excuses for films. But Sandler as an actor ‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs another thing entirely. I liked him in ‚ÄúSpanglish‚Äù and was surprised at his talent in ‚ÄúReign Over Me‚Äù and the astonishing Paul-Thomas Anderson film ‚ÄúPunch-Drunk Love.‚Äù Now he may earn an Oscar nomination. And I‚Äôm on board with that because of his performance in ‚ÄúUncut Gems,‚Äù an unflinching look at a gambling addict and the people in his life ‚Äî some of whom want to kill him. Benny and Josh Safdie (‚ÄúGood Time‚Äù) wrote (with Ronald Bronstein) and directed this drama in which Sandler stars as Howard Ratner, a New York jeweler who would rather gamble than anything else, including spend time with the people he loves. His wife Dinah (Idina Menzel, Elsa‚Äôs voice in the ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù movies) has had it with Howard‚Äôs detachment ‚Äî he isn‚Äôt with her even when he‚Äôs beside her. His mistress Julia (Julia Fox) loves him, but feels uneasy about his jealous nature. Howard‚Äôs biggest problem is his gambling addiction. He owes a lot of money to his brother-in-law Arno (Eric Bogosian). But Howard figures he has a solution: He has purchased an uncut opal straight from an Ethiopian mine, and he plans to sell it for more than $1 million. He continues to gamble and gets in deeper and deeper, lying and trying to manipulate everyone around him while he places bets, ignores his family, hovers over his girlfriend and continues to find himself at odds with more and more people.¬† This is a loud, sometimes shocking film with more violence than you might expect: In some ways, it resembles mobster movies directed by the likes of Martin Scorsese. Not surprisingly, it contains a lot of yelling, not only from Howard but also the other characters, many of whom are exasperated with him. Howard rarely stops talking and shouting, and his family and others simply try to out-yell him to get his attention. NBA star Kevin Garnett plays himself (he‚Äôs very good) as a client who is taken with the uncut opal and thinks it might bring him luck. That means Howard must bet on the game. The character of Howard is unlikable. But he‚Äôs always interesting, and while we watch his downward spiral we can‚Äôt help but wonder how it‚Äôs all going to end in this fast-paced character study that may result in a golden statuette for Sandler.

Brimming with anxious energy, Josh and Benny Safdie‚Äôs latest feature is a densely packed medley of memorable lines, characters and debut acting performances. Reminiscent of their previous outing ‚Äì GOOD TIME ‚Äì UNCUT GEMS nevertheless applies the anxiety-inducing approach polished there in new and interesting ways. Adam Sandler leads as Howard Ratner, a jeweller in New York City‚Äôs Diamond District with a penchant for high-stakes deals and gambling. In a prologue we are introduced, by way of the human misery it has already caused, to a black opal from Ethiopia. Howard has purchased this stone with the intention of auctioning it for a potential seven-figure sum. Demany (Lakeith Stanfield), who recruits clients for Howard in exchange for storage of questionably sourced watches, brings in Kevin Garnett (playing himself) of the Boston Celtics. In awe of the opal, Garnett convinces Howard to let him keep the gem overnight in exchange for his NBA championship ring as collateral, believing the opal confers mystical abilities onto him. Howard has a habit of pawning client belongings as part of a precarious daisy chain of deals, cash, and gambling ‚Äì and his latest gambit starts off a chain reaction he must try to outrun. Much like GOOD TIME, which probably brought on more anxiety headaches than any other film released in 2017, there is rarely a calm moment in UNCUT GEMS. At every stage something is unravelling for our protagonist ‚Äì whether it is his latest bet, someone screwing him over, his family life, his various dodgy business deals, or his relationship with extra-marital girlfriend Julia (Julia Fox). Beyond the excellent performances and the jittery filming style, the music of Daniel Lopatin polishes this prism of anxiety through which we interpret the characters. Similar to the use of the music in GOOD TIME, the strange collection of synth-like curios feels like an uplifting nightmare; the sort of fog of pain and terror which is endured for the supposed pot of gold at the end of its shit-strewn rainbow. ‚Äú‚Ä¶the strange collection of synth-like curios feels like an uplifting nightmare; the sort of fog of pain and terror which is endured for the supposed pot of gold at the end of its shit-strewn rainbow.‚Äù Adam Sandler is reliably excellent in the lead role, retaining sympathy even as his self-destructive and opportunistic behaviour drags more disaster into his world. Howard is a role that demonstrates Sandler‚Äôs curious versatility and duality ‚Äì on the one hand he is denigrated critically for enormously popular but reductive comedies, on the other he is lauded for blackly comedic drama roles in critically lauded independent work. And never the twain shall meet, apparently. Nevertheless, the on-screen likability that makes many of his comedies tolerable is also what gives him the depth to play the likes of Howard Ratner, Danny Meyerowitz or PUNCH-DRUNK LOVE‚Äôs Barry Egan. The Safdies‚Äô film also highlights their capability in eliciting engaging and charismatic performances from debut actors. Julia Fox is an energetic whirlwind and does significant work during the film‚Äôs concluding movements. When Sandler isn‚Äôt on screen she carries the nervous energy of the film. Kevin Garnett moves between rich exuberance and calm dignity with ease, much more easily than any recent NBA player should be expected to (and more so than anyone familiar with the screen career of Shaquille O‚ÄôNeal has a right to anticipate). UNCUT GEMS achieves many things, including weaving a compelling tale of addict behaviour augmented and elevated by all the aforementioned elements. The film communicates Howard‚Äôs anxiety for his next high, his joy in achieving it, and the crushing despair of failing or having the rug pulled from under him. UNCUT GEMS behaves like a wounded great white shark, constantly moving forward lest it dies, but bleeding out nonetheless. It does this, however, with less kinetic style than GOOD TIME: a film that was often found tracking Robert Pattinson at high speed down streets and around corners. UNCUT GEMS is much more at home jittering nervously in enclosed, claustrophobic spaces like Howard‚Äôs car, his double-locked jewellery store, or crowded black-lit nightclubs. The Safdies have not conferred mystical powers onto their film, but like the black opal at its heart, UNCUT GEMS will transfix the viewer by reflecting something a little different back at you depending on what angle you consider it from.

Take 2014‚Äôs¬†Heaven Knows What, which¬†follows a woman torn between her two loves: her boyfriend and heroin. There‚Äôs also 2017‚Äôs¬†Good Time,¬†which¬†shows the aftermath of a botched bank robbery that turns into a race against the clock for survival (a film that further solidified Robert Pattinson‚Äôs art-house cred). In their latest film ‚Äì Uncut Gems¬†‚Äì the Safdies once again create a breakneck-speed film that centers around a law-skirting citizen who can‚Äôt help himself from getting in too deep. Uncut¬†Gems follows sleazy huckster Howard Ratner (Adam Sandler), a fast-talking jeweler whose gambling problems constantly overpower the responsibilities he has as a store manager to his employees and friends (LaKeith Stanfield), his wife (Idina Menzel) and kids, and to his illegitimate girlfriend (Julia Fox). Like any gambler, Howard believes that all of his troubles will be solved with the acquisition of a rare Ethiopian Opal (commonly referred to as ‚Äúthe gamblers gem‚Äù), which he intends to sell at auction for a king‚Äôs fortune. However, his cockiness blocks his better judgment when he lets Celtics star Kevin Garnett (as himself) borrow the gem for a night, hoping that the Opal‚Äôs good luck will help him win the bet he placed on the game. When the Opal isn‚Äôt returned on time as promised, Howard is thrust into an intense marathon throughout New York City to track down the Opal, not only to save his future investment but also himself from nasty debt collectors who‚Äôve decided that Howard‚Äôs time is up. What follows is dazzling, anxiety-inducing mania that spares no moment for viewers to catch their breath. Handheld and grainy camerawork (Darius Khondji serves as director of photography)¬†lend further¬†pulpy¬†energy to this world that consists of overly-crowded nightclubs, sidewalk screaming matches, and dimly lit casinos. As for the score,¬†Brooklyn-based artist¬†Oneohtrix Point Never,¬†who also scored¬†Good Time,¬†lends¬†electronic and experimental compositions (arcade-style¬†sounds are reminiscent of collecting gold coins in Super Mario video games)¬†that help the audience escape reality and get lost in the world¬†of the madness of the¬†Safdies. Returning to his more dramatic side, Adam Sandler delivers a stunning performance as a man on the edge of a mental breakdown. Those who found Punch Drunk Love and The Meyerowitz Stories a solid platform for the more ‚Äúserious‚Äù Sandler to excel, Uncut Gems will be a welcomed return to the big screen. Proving himself to be one of the most dynamic actors of our time, under the direction of the Safdie‚Äôs provocative direction, Sandler‚Äôs natural talent is accelerated to new heights. Aside from transforming big-name actors into unrecognizable characters, the Safdies also have a gift when it comes to scouting amateur talent. Here, a majority of the cast are non-actors, including Kevin Garnett, The Weeknd, and Julia Fox (who credits Uncut Gems¬†as her first film). This deliberate decision to cast non-professionals gives off a sense of liberation and unrestricted actions not common in feature films. Like¬†Howard Ratner ‚Äì a maximalist through and through ‚Äì¬†Uncut Gems is very much a reflection of his go hard or go home lifestyle. Unsettling in all of the right ways, this film is no doubt a treasure to be sought out and celebrated.

Deadliest Catch or Sexiest Catch? It's hard to tell at first. Because if that really is a mermaid that fishing trawler hauls out of the Bering Sea in the dead of night, we don't get a good look at it. Whatever it is quickly mauls a fisherman and then scuttles off into the boat's inky hold. And what are the odds that a bunch of US Navy SEALs would immediately abseil down from a helicopter, dart the... creature... and then make off with it and with the wounded fisherman? While it's possible to imagine the current US president establishing a military mermaid taskforce after being gulled by one of the Discovery Channel's fake mermaid documentaries, things still seem a bit, well, fishy. Back on dry land, the small fishing town of Bristol Cove, Washington, is in the swing of its annual mermaid festival, a nice little tourism earner built on mermaid legends dating back to the time of the town's founding. Local trawler magnate Ted Pownall (David Cubitt) takes centre stage at the official proceedings, while events are observed with some displeasure by shopkeeper Helen Hawkins (ever-delightful New Zealander Rena Owen, most recently seen in The Gloaming). One notable absentee is Pownall's marine-biologist son, Ben (Alex Roe), who would rather be down at the local marine research centre with his girlfriend, Maddy (Fola Evans-Akingbola). All well and good, but isn't there a certain mermaid-shaped piece missing? Without giving too much away, let's just say that there's a new girl in town, slightly built, elfin featured, seemingly mute, and possessed of unsettling, twitchy mannerisms that might lead some folks to assume that she's a member of the local methamphetamine community. Belgian actress Eline Powell (a recognisable face to your more tragic Game of Thrones tragics), is terrific in the role, combining the artlessness of the ingenue with the nervy menace of the cornered animal. Equally impressive is the way the effects department handles the mermaid transformations, with echoes of werewolf movies adding to the sense of primal danger. It's all quite well put together, a cut above your usual non-premium, small-town-monster-mystery-meets-military-conspiracy kind of show, and the early episodes deliver some neat surprises. The town's back story of mermaid genocide has obvious parallels with the dispossession of Native Americans, but the series doesn't seem intent on labouring the point. Worth checking out. Workaholics' Adam DeVine and the disembodied voice of Rose Byrne are wonderfully puerile fun in this sweet but dirty-minded rom-com from the makers of The Hangover. DeVine plays mobile-phone addict Phil, a friendless dork who lives in San Francisco and works writing listicles in a clickbait sweatshop. When Phil gets a new phone its Siri-style personal-assistant program (Byrne) turns out to be a foul-mouthed rogue intent on improving his life by tearing it apart. Wanda Sykes is an absolute show-stealer in her little role. Emotionally authentic but procedurally dodgy, this bright-and-busy British series has Top Boy star Ashley Walters and Sherlock's Amanda Abbington as coppers policing Brighton's pebbly beaches. Walters' no-nonsense PC is particularly aggrieved at being made training officer for the superintendent's callow, queue-jumping son (Jacob Ifan). Brighton quickly reveals itself to be a sun-drenched hotbed of daylight ram-raids, nudism, truancy, parkour and racist violence. Slightly rote, but watchable. Adam Sandler's dramatic performances are so much better than his woeful latter-day comedies that he really ought to quit the comedy business altogether. He even got some Oscar buzz for Uncut Gems. It's a brilliantly exhausting movie that gaffer-tapes us to motormouth New York gem dealer and degenerate gambler Howard Ratner (Sandler) as he tells lie after lie and pulls scam after scam trying to get out from under some violent debt collectors. The thrill and despair of the addict are palpable. Even by Narcos standards, the first season of Narcos: Mexico was a harrowing one, leading up as it did to the real-life torture and murder of DEA agent Enrique "Kiki" Camarena (so memorably played by Michael Pe√±a). And just when it looked as though the blowback might finally bring down cocaine kingpin Felix Gallardo (Diego Luna), Mexican institutional corruption put him right back on top of the heap. In the new second season it's still 1985 but Gallardo faces a new threat in DEA agent Walt Breslin (Scoot McNairy), who is leading a posse of DEA agents on a campaign of revenge kidnappings. But might the spider become the fly once more? As ever, it's exquisitely written, cast and shot, making great use of Mexico's stunning landscapes, opulent haciendas and colourful '80s fashions. The series does a fine job too of keeping the viewer straight about a big cast of characters ‚Äì including a little up-and-comer by the name of Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman (Alejandro Edda) ‚Äì and of placing events in the context of American involvement in the war in Nicaragua. Brilliant. It's fitting that the first track we hear in this celebratory but emotionally dappled documentary is Wilson Pickett's Land of 1000 Dances. The rich, elemental energy of the recording encapsulates what would become known as the Muscle Shoals sound. Pickett, Aretha Franklin, Percy Sledge and countless others are on hand to explain how an unlikely outpost of racial harmony in 1960s Alabama changed the courses of lives and careers and brought us some of the most soulful music ever recorded.

Los directores de Good Time regresan a Netflix con Diamantes en bruto, ofreciendo otra dosis de entretenimiento tan fren√©tico y vertiginoso como insustancial e irritante. Joyas, deudas, apuestas y matones se al√≠an en este banquete de vulgaridad y bullicio dif√≠cil de digerir. Inexplicables las buenas cr√≠ticas recibidas en los medios y la nota de 6,9 con la que se pasea en FilmAffinity ‚Äìla misma que Burning que es una obra maestra‚Äì. Los hermanos Safdie desechan por completo la sutileza y la elegancia para proponer una amalgama de situaciones ca√≥ticas llenas de conversaciones que se superponen y personajes que se dedican a lanzarse improperios. Posiblemente sea una de las pel√≠culas m√°s molestas que he visto en los √∫ltimos a√±os. Parece que est√° hecha por alguien hiperactivo con d√©ficit de atenci√≥n que no deja que ning√∫n momento respire. Una aplicaci√≥n pr√°ctica del concepto de horror vacui orientado a la generaci√≥n del Instagram. Lo √∫nico salvable de Diamantes en bruto es la actuaci√≥n de Adam Sandler, la presencia m√°s o menos carism√°tica de Julia Fox y Kevin Garnett y alguna que otra escena moderadamente interesante. En general, es una pel√≠cula para pasar el rato y poco m√°s, aunque exige unos niveles importantes de paciencia y que te adentres en ella con el cerebro medio desconectado. Tampoco me ha gustado Diamantes en bruto, pero debo admitir que la actuaci√≥n de Adam Sandler estaba a tope. Solamente esto me ha hecho terminar la peli. Creo que el problema con el review viene por el lado de la subjetividad. El arte es as√≠, a cada uno nos provoca cosas diferentes. Yo veo la actuaci√≥n de Sandler casi excelente, aunque no consigue quitarse cierto no s√© qu√© de su propia personalidad, como que siempre lleva algo de su persona a sus personajes que interpreta. Eso le pasa a muchos actores. Pero el desempe√±o en este papel igual es excelente, salvo por ese detalle, que no le quita nada al m√©rito de interpretar una personalidad que no s√© si todos conocemos o estamos habituados a ver.
Otro tema aparte es la trama, que si bien es muy interesante, uno puede no estar de √°nimo para ver un thriller y sobre todo ver relaciones disfuncionales, una persecuci√≥n casi constante al propio personaje por sus acreedores y a la vez pensar que eso pasa en la vida real, y el tratar de ponerse en el lugar del personaje (que al menos es lo que yo hago cuando veo una pel√≠cula para entenderlo mejor), creo que da un ‚Äúsock‚Äù importante al espectador que puede o no gustar, pero que cuenta una historia que bien puede ser real, sin problemas, al menos en un lugar tan fren√©tico y materialista como Nueva York.
As√≠ que mi opini√≥n sobre la pel√≠cula es  que es realmente muy buena, s√≥lo que hay que estar de humor para ver un thriller tan demandante.

Los hermanos Safdie, Joshua y Benny, han participado en el debate abierto sobre si ver cine en salas para ello, solo ah√≠, es parecido a verlo en plataformas como la de Netflix. No solo han participado en la discusi√≥n, sino que ahora ofrecen un buen filme en dicha plataforma titulado Diamantes en bruto (2019). Los Safdie escribieron: ‚ÄúLa cruda realidad es que, como promedio, el p√∫blico experimenta en video el 80% de vida de cada pel√≠cula. No significa que no debamos hacer todo lo que podamos por proteger la experiencia inspiradora, humana y relajante pr√°ctica colectiva de ver una pel√≠cula en el cine‚Äù; es una declaraci√≥n que, bien analizada, defiende ambas opciones. Como cr√≠tico, uno desea que hubiese solo buen cine (l√≥gico), algo as√≠ como que tengamos mejores pel√≠culas que superh√©roes, vengan de donde vengan estos. Es una l√°stima que no sea as√≠, por lo menos con la gran industria de Hollywood. En lo personal lamento no poder ver Diamantes en bruto en la pantalla grande de una buena sala de cine. De una vez, he de aclarar que dicho filme alcanza f√°cilmente la categor√≠a de buena pel√≠cula, pero sin llegar a ser extraordinaria. Que est√© o no postulada a un Oscar me tiene sin cuidado, ¬°para lo que significa esa estatuilla! Mejor pensemos en la buena trama que tiene la pel√≠cula, que comienza en Etiop√≠a, en 2010, con la obtenci√≥n de un valioso √≥palo. Luego llega a una situaci√≥n en un hospital en Nueva York, en el 2012, que nos permite conocer al personaje de la pel√≠cula, de presencia absoluta durante el metraje, por lo que el guion pierde la habilidad de manejar subtramas que le habr√≠an venido como anillo al dedo. Una vez que Diamantes en bruto se concentra en su personaje, el n√∫cleo dram√°tico pasa por la actuaci√≥n del actor que lo encarna, en este caso un histri√≥n poco valorado que ustedes saben qui√©n es: Adam Sandler, quien tiene un registro distinto. Sandler puede ser simp√°tico o no con sus comedias y se le ve casi siempre inexpresivo (pero sin la grandiosidad de un actor eterno en ese estilo, como Buster Keaton). Esta vez pasa a ser lo contrario: en exceso expresivo, con m√°s muecas que las de Robert de Niro en su peor pel√≠cula. Adam Sandler sigue siendo un mal actor. Es una l√°stima, porque aqu√≠ su actuaci√≥n siempre desaforada le hace perder proporci√≥n al buen argumento del filme. De paso, la trama necesita de m√°s equilibrio en su ritmo, por lo que confunde la intensidad dram√°tica con el desorden visual o la agitaci√≥n injustificada. Eso s√≠, he de aceptar que Diamantes en bruto sostiene en firme su denuncia social y nos muestra los juegos sucios o mafiosos que se dan en una sociedad manejada por el af√°n capitalista de la codicia, donde no hay √©tica alguna, y donde aparecen las apuestas como m√©todo supuestamente f√°cil para enriquecerse. Igual con los asuntos raciales. Creo que Diamantes en bruto ha tenido una buena campa√±a medi√°tica que la ha sobrevalorado; pero siempre es filme que uno debe recomendar y Netflix da ocasi√≥n para verla. En beneficio de la transparencia y para evitar distorsiones del debate p√∫blico por medios inform√°ticos o aprovechando el anonimato, la secci√≥n de comentarios est√° reservada para nuestros suscriptores para comentar sobre el contenido de los art√≠culos, no sobre los autores. El nombre completo y n√∫mero de c√©dula del suscriptor aparecer√° autom√°ticamente con el comentario.

The follow-up to Good Time from Safdie brothers Josh and Benny feels similarly frantic but also proves darker and more unsettling, with a strong, if occasionally infuriating, performance by no less than Adam Sandler.  Having coaxed memorable work from another problem child, Robert Pattinson, in Good Time, here Josh and Benny Safdie similarly push the goofy-comedy-friendly Sandler in new and disquieting directions. Sandler can really act (see Paul Thomas Anderson‚Äôs Punch-Drunk Love, Jason Reitman‚Äôs Men, Women & Children and Noah Baumbach‚Äôs The Meyerowitz Stories for proof) but rarely stretches himself, and while he was cast after the filmmakers first considered Harvey Keitel, Sacha Baron Cohen and Jonah Hill, he‚Äôs still awfully good. Back in 2012 Howard Ratner (Sandler) runs KMH Gems & Jewelry in New York‚Äôs ‚ÄòDiamond District‚Äô, and his life is an increasingly dangerous mess. A compulsive gambling addict who lives and works in chaos, Howard is used to daily situations (like Pattinson‚Äôs Connie in Good Time) where a hundred things are happening at once and everyone‚Äôs talking (and swearing) incessantly. But chances are the viewer isn‚Äôt, and this sort of profanely Robert-Altman-like atmosphere should prove hard to take for more than a few. Howard divides his time between his estranged wife Dinah (Broadway star and Frozen voicer Idina Menzel) and employee and girlfriend Julia (Julia Fox), and owes $100 000 to his loan shark brother-in-law Arno (scary Eric Bogosian), who keeps harassing him with help from some seriously nasty guys. Our flawed protagonist receives a rare black opal first glimpsed in the opening sequence, and although he hopes to auction it off for big money, pay off Arno and then spend quality time with Julia, he instead winds up lending it to one of his favourite customers, Kevin Garnett (the former pro basketballer playing himself rather well). There‚Äôs a heavy suggestion that Kevin has glimpsed
something mystical deep within the opal and wants to hold onto it for luck, yet
Howard could certainly do with a fair bit of that himself, as he makes several
more bad decisions and gives the similarly foolish hero of The Gambler
(original 1974, remake 2014) a run for his ill-gotten money. Impressive but somewhat exhausting at 135 minutes, this still has a great deal to admire, from the pitch of nervous tension, to the entire supporting cast (some of whom go uncredited), to Daniel Lopatin‚Äôs (who makes electronic music as Oneohtrix Point Never) musical score, to Sandler‚Äôs pretty daring playing.  And yet the frenetic aspects here are a little wearying, and you can‚Äôt help but long for Howard to yell, ‚ÄúQuiet!‚Äù, and plead with everyone to talk one at a damn time. And, with an F-bomb tally surely reaching into the hundreds, the film certainly lives up to its uncut title.
Most of us, if we're honest, will see at least a little bit of ourselves - albeit in our worst moments - in Sandler's Ratner, and that is what makes Uncut Gems memorable.
I was pleasantly surprised at the choice of material for Adam Sandler and how well he does in the role of Howard.
The Safdie Brothers manage a constant cranking, winding up of tension, as this escalating situation gets from bad to worse, as Sandler's character makes bad decision after bad decision.
This is an energy shot of a movie, a dose of which will leave viewers jittery, but craving more.
Fans of The Waterboy should go into Uncut Gems with plenty of high quality H2O to make up for all the juices they'll be projectile-sweating out of their pores.

No, no es Despu√©s de hora, aunque Martin Scorsese sea uno de los productores. Pero esta pel√≠cula de los hermanos Benny y Josh Safdie es como si Good Time: Viviendo al l√≠mite, con Robert Pattinson, con la que compitieron en 2017 en el Festival de Cannes, hubiera sido el aperitivo -para el espectador- y la mejor preparaci√≥n para este convite. Adam Sandler se meti√≥ a medio mundo en el bolsillo con su interpretaci√≥n de Howard Ratner. Salvando las distancias, lo mismo logr√≥ una d√©cada atr√°s Guillermo Francella con su Pablo Sandoval en El secreto de sus ojos. OK, Sandler tuvo en Embriagado de amor (2002), de Paul Thomas Anderson, una oportunidad que no supo aprovechar. Ambos cambiaron la consideraci√≥n del p√∫blico, que los ve con otras aptitudes e idoneidades que les desconoc√≠an. Sandler se olvida el payaso en la sala de vestuario -aunque, inevitablemente, los Safdie le dejan servidas un par de humoradas- y se pone en el ropaje de un hiperkin√©tico joyero de Nueva York. Nada parece irle bien, le debe dinero (y mucho) a m√°s de un prestamista, est√° por separarse de su esposa, cela a su amante. Y conf√≠a solamente en una carta. Una carta fuerte. Porque Howard es un jugador empedernido. Un tipo que no puede tener m√°s de cien d√≥lares en el bolsillo que va y los apuesta. Compr√≥ un √≥palo negro, con varios kilates, que los mineros etiop√≠es le han vendido por la d√©cima parte de lo que √©l supone que obtendr√° cuando lo subaste. As√≠ piensa saldar todas sus deudas y dejar de escapar hacia adelante, como viene haciendo d√≠a tras d√≠a, hora tras hora, segundo a segundo. Esa vida fren√©tica se compatibiliza con el ritmo que los Safdie le imprimen a Diamantes en bruto. Uno, sentado en el living de su casa, viendo esta coproducci√≥n de Netflix, siente que est√° en movimiento continuo. ¬øHacia d√≥nde? Hacia el mismo lado. Porque cuando hay indicios de que Howard va a zafar, es √©l mismo el que parece -no parece, lo hace- boicotearse. Es 2012, pero poco importa m√°s que para que Kevin Garnett, el ala pivot por entonces de los Boston Celtics, sea uno de los que quede fascinado con el √≥palo. ‚ÄúEstoy conectado con esta piedra, irradia energ√≠a‚Äù, dice el basquetbolista que se interpreta a s√≠ mismo. ¬øY qu√© hace Howard? Se lo presta -a d√≠as de la subasta- y va y empe√±a el anillo de campe√≥n de la NBA de los Celtics. Si hay algo que los Safdie saben es mantener la tensi√≥n. No importa los d√≠as que pasen, los lugares donde Howard se mueva y hable, o mienta y enga√±e. Hay una idea de estar corriendo contra el tiempo, que es lo que atrapa. Tambi√©n rescataron a varios int√©rpretes, alguno como una suerte de gui√±o (John Amos es un vecino de Howard), llamaron a The Weeknd, el ex de Selena Gomez para tambi√©n hacer de s√≠ mismo. Y a Eric Bogossian (La radio ataca) y a Judd Hirsch (el psic√≥logo de Gente como uno) les dieron dos papeles de importancia. Suele suceder que cuando se hablan maravillas de una pel√≠cula o de una actuaci√≥n, al verlas la experiencia sufra un desencanto. Diamantes en bruto no es Guas√≥n, que tienen en com√∫n la sensaci√≥n de agobio, y que tuvieron sus premi√®res casi al mismo tiempo, una en el Festival de Toronto y la otra en la Mostra de Venecia. Y as√≠ como Joaquin Phoenix va a ganar el Oscar y Sandler lo ver√°, como ha hecho con todas las ceremonias, en su casa, ambos actores logran acaparar toda la atenci√≥n sobre ellos. De acuerdo, no es solamente la interpretaci√≥n, hay una historia que engancha y atrapa.
Sandler puts everything into his performance. [Full review in Spanish]

Synopsis:¬†Howard Ratner (Adam Sandler) embarks on a long day‚Äôs journey into night as he attempts to avoid creditors while leveraging uncut opals that came from an Ethiopian mine. Review:¬†In another of their tour de forces of frantic contingency, the Safdie brothers‚Äô Uncut Gems¬†may have even surpassed their previous minor masterpiece¬†Good Time¬†as some sort of cinematic parable on the sheer nauseous toxicity of a life lived on the edge in New York City. It‚Äôs very much in the lineage of¬†Good Time: the narrative built around unfurling contingencies, the de facto real time feel, and the distinctive stylisation (roving cinematography that approximates the unfolding mess, the fractured synth score, and the lurid neons and chromes of nocturnal NYC). As with¬†Good Time, it‚Äôs a thrilling and breathless journey ‚Äì the Safdies suck you almost viscerally into Howard Ratner (a stellar turn by Adam Sandler) and the conveyor belt of crises he‚Äôs forced to manage and/or evade. And much like Good Time, my only marginal, perhaps even churlish, criticism is that the Sadfies almost try to oversell this manic, stressful world view once or twice, especially through the sinister and jagged synthesiser chords that play too much as a literal manifestation of the on-screen chaos.

Hay un momento de¬†Diamantes en bruto ‚Äìuna aut√©ntica obra maestra, dig√°moslo de entrada‚Äì, en el que The Weeknd, que se interpreta a s√≠ mismo, exige que pongan las luces negras antes de cantar para un reducido grupo de incondicionales en un exclusivo club de Manhattan. La escena tiene su miga. En primer lugar, porque conecta¬†Uncut Gems (t√≠tulo original, m√°s cortito) con la est√©tica de la anterior, y no menos magistral, pel√≠cula de los Safdie, Good Time (2017), una odisea nocturna que se caracteriza por la fotograf√≠a fluorescente de Sean Price Williams, aqu√≠ revelado por la fotograf√≠a nerviosa y los planos cortos de Darius Khondji. El p√∫blico exclusivo de la discoteca tambi√©n podr√≠a simbolizar a la discreta camarilla de locos seguidores de la que han gozado los Safdie hasta la fecha, incluso con Good Time, una pel√≠cula incre√≠blemente maltratada que, a pesar de haber competido por la Palma de Oro, apenas si recibi√≥ premios, y se estren√≥ de tapadillo en Netflix, adem√°s de estrellarse contra muros de obtusa incomprensi√≥n. Esperamos que Uncut Gems ‚Äìen Netflix, a partir del 31 de enero‚Äì corra mejor suerte, aunque s√≥lo sea por la estrecha relaci√≥n que su m√°ximo protagonista, un extraordinario Adam Sandler, mantiene con la plataforma desde sus inicios. En Sandler recae la responsabilidad del reconocimiento de los Safdie.   Dejando de lado que The Weeknd se consider√≥ como un aut√©ntico revolucionario en el √°mbito del rap y r&b ‚Äìal igual que los Safdie en el mundillo del indie americano, que ya padec√≠a falta de autenticidad‚Äì la escena tambi√©n nos trae a la mente El rey de Nueva York (Abel Ferrara, 1990), la pel√≠cula que marc√≥ un antes y un despu√©s, con aquel bailoteante Christopher Walken, en la cin√©fila relaci√≥n entre el hip hop y el mundo del hampa. No es extra√±o que im√°genes de otras pel√≠culas nos bombardeen mientras contemplamos (extasiados) Diamantes en bruto, porque, sin ser en este caso una referencia expl√≠cita, los hermanos¬†Josh y Benny Safdie, tal y como ellos mismos nos revelaron en¬†Go Get Some Rosemary (2009), tienen alma de proyeccionistas. Les encanta comentar sus referentes en las entrevistas, y sus pel√≠culas se construyen a partir del cine del pasado, para proyectarlo hacia un futuro que, sobre todo gracias a ellos, ya est√° aqu√≠. As√≠, si dijimos que Good Time es el¬†Libertad condicional (Ulu Grosbard, 1978) del siglo XXI, con¬†Robert Pattinson corriendo en la noche como si fuera Max Dembo, tambi√©n podemos asegurar, sin que nos tiemble la mano, que Uncut Gems, bien podr√≠a ser¬†El asesinato de un corredor de apuestas chino (John Cassavetes, 1976) del Nuevo Milenio, y lo siento si, dejando de lado esa Nueva York que es algo m√°s que el decorado del universo Safdie, he tirado de dos referentes muy de la Costa Oeste. El filme de Grosbard es ineludible al tratarse de la adaptaci√≥n de la novela de Edward Bunker ‚Äìya saben, Mr. Brown‚Äì, posiblemente el escritor que mejor ha sabido, por venir de ah√≠, describir los bajos fondos de la sociedad norteamericana, algo en lo que los Safdie tambi√©n se han convertido en expertos. De Bunker tambi√©n han heredado el estupor de la violencia. Es decir, el impacto de esa violencia seca, no espectacularizada, que tambi√©n se da, y no poco, en Uncut Gems. Podr√≠amos seguir tirando de ah√≠, y llegar hasta la m√°s espectacular¬†Heat (Michael Mann, 1995), pel√≠cula asesorada por Bunker, s√≥lo para relacionarla con¬†Ladr√≥n (1981), del mismo Mann, que tiene, como Uncut Gems, un poderos√≠simo personaje central, aquel no menos inmenso James Caan, y luce una est√©tica que a su vez tambi√©n era una mezcla de suciedad setentera y sintes ochenteros, con¬†Tangerine Dream como antepasados directos de Daniel Lopatin, alias Oneohtrix Point Never, que firma las bandas sonoras tanto de Good Time como de Uncut Gems.  Podr√≠amos seguir ad eternum con el juego de los referentes, pero concentr√©monos en la pel√≠cula que nos ocupa, y en su epicentro: Adam Sandler, que posiblemente brinda la interpretaci√≥n m√°s memorable de su carrera. √âl es Howard Ratner, un joyero jud√≠o del distrito de diamantes de Nueva York, endeudado hasta las cejas, y adicto al doble o nada, en un perpetua hu√≠da hacia adelante con la que bordea constantemente el abismo. Ratner puede parecer un personaje absolutamente despreciable ‚Äìego√≠sta, lud√≥pata y carente de escr√∫pulos‚Äì, que ya ha sido calificado con acierto de dickensiano (no dir√≠amos lo mismo de su amante, la deslumbrante Julia Fox), pero no resulta nada dif√≠cil identificarse con √©l, en estos tiempos de fren√©tica inseguridad, am√©n de que los Safdie saben muy bien c√≥mo dibujar e inyectar humanidad hasta al m√°s nimio de sus personajes. Como el Cosmo Vittelli de Cassavetes, Ratner es un endeudado contra las cuerdas, perseguido por sus acreedores, que se mueve en un entorno que exuda verdad gracias a la c√°mara nerviosa de los Safdie, que remite al estilo directo del documental, como a la galer√≠a de personajes, en buena parte sacados de la calle, con los que se cruza a lo largo de 135 minutos que se disfrutan con un nudo en el est√≥mago. Los Safdie vuelven a demostrar que son maestros de ese ritmo adrenal√≠nico (no por nada se les pas√≥ por la cabeza un remake de L√≠mite 48 Horas, cl√°sico thriller a contrarreloj), que nos retuerce las entra√±as, en una mezcla perversa de angustia y placer.   Scorsese, que se sum√≥ al proyecto como productor ejecutivo, tuvo que tener claro que hoy en d√≠a no hay nadie como ellos para recuperar el realismo sucio de los 70, y empaparlo en un humor lis√©rgico, profundamente contempor√°neo que tampoco le es ajeno (recu√©rdese la magistral El lobo de Wall Street). Good Time y Diamantes en bruto forman una doble sesi√≥n imbatible para los que buscan thrillers realistas y trepidantes, pero tambi√©n son pel√≠culas esenciales para cualquier cin√©filo que se precie. Un retrato de tan honda humanidad como el que protagoniza Adam Sandler no se ve muy a menudo. Est√° de Oscar, aunque, claro, la pulcra, apolillada y conservadora Academia de Hollywood nunca le entregar√≠a una dorada estatuilla a un marrano. Eso que se pierden.

Magic rocks, diamond-encrusted Furbies, Adam Sandler: all the arcane forces of the universe come to bear on Josh and Benny Safdie‚Äôs Uncut Gems (available on Netflix January 31), an electrifying sprint through Manhattan‚Äôs high-stakes, fame-adjacent netherworld of sports betting and Midtown hustlers that‚Äôs as much cosmic fable as gauntlet-running indie thriller. ‚ÄúThey say you can see the whole universe in opals,‚Äù says middle-aged jeweller Howard Ratner (Sandler), spellbound by the newly excavated gemstone that sets the plot in motion, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs how fuckin‚Äô old they are.‚Äù The ancient power awakens in the film‚Äôs opening moments, the camera swooping like a locust across an Ethiopian mine to find a bunch of workers, overseen by their multinational bosses, in an opal-struck frenzy that recalls nothing so much as the discovery of the demon idol in The Exorcist. In one of their dazzling, amusing formal tricks, the Safdies then push in on the rainbow colours of the gem (a high-tech version of the eerie shot in Australian filmmaker Alena Lodkina‚Äôs Strange Colours [2017]), via what feels like the entire universe, only to emerge right among the squishy innards of Howard himself, prostrate, mid colonoscopy, in a New York doctor‚Äôs office. Talk about a possession. Set to the New Age electronic score of Daniel Lopatin (aka Oneohtrix Point Never), which channels Tomita‚Äôs bleeps in the Safdies‚Äô Heaven Knows What (2014), the sequence has a strange, holistic calm ‚Äì in stark contrast to the nervy, chattering chaos of the city‚Äôs Diamond District, the crucible of the film‚Äôs action. It‚Äôs here, in this seemingly lost-in-time, quintessential New York space ‚Äì just seconds from the oppressive jumbotron fantasia of Times Square ‚Äì that Howard, slippery in a leather jacket and the leisure polo of a galactic card shark, holds court as a manic duke of the jewel trade. He flips watches, rings and memorabilia to clients, from shady goombahs to slumming sports stars (often lured into his orbit by his wily assistant, Demany, played by Lakeith Stanfield.) Howard‚Äôs is a world of spinning plates: crumbling family life with his wife Dinah (Idina Menzel) on Long Island; a slick uptown pad and a mistress, Julia (Julia Fox), in the city; and rising gambling debts that have put a pack of gravelly voiced goons, led by his grouchy brother-in-law, Arno (Eric Bogosian), on his tail. Stirred into the mix is NBA star Kevin Garnett (played by the man himself), whom¬†Howard tempts with his custom-bejewelled Furbies ‚Äì a totem of some bizarre, alternate consumer timeline. Their bugged-out eyes, savoured in disconcertingly goofy close-up, seem to portend the nerve-wracking delirium to follow. But Garnett is quickly ensnared by the opal, believing it will bring him a winning streak on the court, while Howard thinks the opal‚Äôs energy comes from its discovery by displaced African Jews. Each is bewitched in his own way, the uncut rock, like some Tolkienian ring, giving shape to its beholder‚Äôs best and worst instincts. (In one sequence, Garnett touches the gem and triggers a hallucinatory montage that seems to span both the history of Africa and the NBA playoffs.) The film is set in 2012, itself a strange interzone where The Weeknd (also appearing as his younger self) is a fledgling R&B singer on the verge of stardom (‚ÄúWhat the fuck is a Weeknd?‚Äù grumbles Howard), and Instagram posts are still framed by the blocky queen blue ‚Äì a world away from the present, where the app currently features Uncut Gems selfie filters with gold chains and Furby pendants for a new generation of aspirant bling ringers. The Safdies, who grew up between Manhattan and Queens, were just lo-fi filmmakers at the time, but their subsequent ascent has been spectacular. This is the brothers‚Äô first film since 2017‚Äôs Good Time, a breakout hit that ricocheted bleached-blond scammer Robert Pattinson through a pinball machine of similarly random circumstance, and also revelled in their love for the city that reared them ‚Äì in all of its cacophonous, race-and-class melting-pot glory. Pattinson‚Äôs work with the Safdies was seen less as star transformation than an extension of his daring independent turn, but Sandler‚Äôs performance ‚Äì notoriously, and foolishly, snubbed in recent Oscar nominations ‚Äì has drawn the predictable backhanded praise reserved for the comedian. For years, Sandler has been anathema to a certain type of snob, the kind of middle-brow cineastes who insist that the actor‚Äôs only good¬†performances exist in the likes of Paul Thomas Anderson‚Äôs Punch-Drunk Love (2002) or Noah Baumbach‚Äôs The Meyerowitz Stories (2017) ‚Äì ‚Äúproper‚Äù films seen as aberrations in a career otherwise dedicated to peddling broad comedies. This approach diminishes Sandler‚Äôs gift for manic character study and unpredictable comic rhythm; tolerated in ‚Äúdumb‚Äù classics like Billy Madison (1995) and Happy Gilmore (1996), sure, but sadly overlooked in his later works, such as the inclusive, hilarious Zionist parody You Don‚Äôt Mess With the Zohan (2008) or his much-maligned, though very charming, gender-switch pantomime Jack and Jill (2011) (which also happens to include Al Pacino‚Äôs best 21st-century performance this side of The Irishman). Sandler‚Äôs performance in Uncut Gems isn‚Äôt some great metamorphosis, as such; it‚Äôs Sandler doing what he‚Äôs always done best: cultivating an uneasy, livewire anxiety that pulses on top of his characters‚Äô essentially humble, flawed humanity. There‚Äôs a scene here in which his badly beaten-up Howard ‚Äì tissue paper jammed up his nostrils, a pendulum of drool swinging from his lips ‚Äì is whimpering in his lover‚Äôs arms, and it‚Äôs all but indistinguishable from any of his man-baby tantrums of yore. I felt bad for the guy but also cackled, and I suspect directors and star would be happy with either response (after all, what‚Äôs funnier, and more absurd, than human plight). Sandler‚Äôs genius is his ability to convey that highest mode of expression: a synthesis of sincerity and satire, wrapped up in a ball of snot. And where plenty of movies have depicted the hapless travails of Dostoevskian putzes chasing that one lucky score ‚Äì usually at their comedic expense ‚Äì the Safdies are, like Sandler, empathetic chroniclers of the desperate and down-on-their-luck. They don‚Äôt pity or patronise Howard but embrace him, and we share in his euphoria ‚Äì despite that fact that he‚Äôs kind of a dirtbag. Likewise, there‚Äôs a surfeit of wonderfully drawn, rough-around-the-edges supporting performances: among them the fantastic Julia Fox, holding her head defiantly high in tandem with cinematographer Darius Khondji‚Äôs breathtaking tracking shots; and Frozen balladeer Menzel, who goes from priceless, exasperated disdain at her husband‚Äôs exploits to full-tilt comedic withering. ‚ÄúYour face is so stupid,‚Äù she screams at Howard, on the verge of post-Passover divorce. ‚ÄúYou are the most annoying person I have ever met.‚Äù Even richer: an appearance from real-life New York character Wayne Diamond, who drops into the action like a leathery angel of fate, and a cameo from Good Times (1974‚Äì79) and Coming to America (1988) star John Amos, which I half expected to conclude with him telling Howard to ‚ÄúStay off the drugs.‚Äù As Howard drills himself ever deeper into trouble, and the opal carves its own path toward destiny, Uncut Gems barely has time to pause for breath, like a playoff game starring New York‚Äôs jewellery‚Äìdealing underworld where Lopatin‚Äôs high-strung score and Billy Joel‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Stranger‚Äù stand in for the courtside ‚ÄúCharge‚Äù fanfare. (You‚Äôd better believe the Safdies crank that shit loud.) ‚ÄúWhat is it about you Jews and basketball?‚Äù Demany asks Howard at one point, and indeed both character (who‚Äôs frequently seen glued to the game) and filmmakers (whose Lenny Cooke followed a teenage ball player) are obsessed to an infectious degree. When Howard, rapt in a Celtics game, exclaimed, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all down to the last two minutes,‚Äù he wasn‚Äôt kidding: Uncut Gems burns itself right to the wire, leading to an astonishingly tense and funny climax ‚Äì set against the outcome of the actual 2012 Boston versus Philadelphia playoff match ‚Äì that pivots on, of all things, a faulty office door buzzer. When the camera finally returns to flesh, and into the cosmos, you can almost feel the universe chuckling like some celestial bookmaker, shades tilted, pearly smile flashing, as if to throw the much-memed Sandler moment back at humanity: ‚ÄúThis is how I win.‚Äù Magic rocks, diamond-encrusted Furbies, Adam Sandler: all the arcane forces of the universe come to bear on Josh and Benny Safdie‚Äôs Uncut Gems (available on Netflix January 31), an electrifying sprint through Manhattan‚Äôs high-stakes, fame-adjacent netherworld of sports betting and Midtown hustlers that‚Äôs as much cosmic fable as gauntlet-running indie thriller. ‚ÄúThey say you can see the whole universe in opals,‚Äù says middle-aged jeweller Howard Ratner (Sandler), spellbound by the newly excavated gemstone that sets the plot in motion, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs how fuckin‚Äô old they are.‚Äù The ancient power awakens in the film‚Äôs opening moments, the camera swooping like a locust across an Ethiopian mine to find a bunch of workers, overseen by their multinational bosses, in an opal-struck frenzy that recalls nothing so much as the discovery of the demon idol in The Exorcist. In one of their dazzling, amusing formal tricks, the Safdies then push in on the rainbow colours of the gem (a high-tech version of the eerie shot in Australian filmmaker Alena Lodkina‚Äôs Strange Colours [2017]), via what feels like the entire universe, only to emerge right among the squishy innards of Howard himself, prostrate, mid colonoscopy, in a New York doctor‚Äôs office. Talk about a possession. Set to the New Age electronic score of Daniel Lopatin (aka Oneohtrix Point Never), which channels Tomita‚Äôs bleeps in the Safdies‚Äô Heaven Knows What (2014), the sequence has... 
There is nowhere quite like The Monthly. We are told that we live in a time of diminished attention spans; a time where the 24-hour-news-cycle has produced a collective desire for hot takes and brief summaries of the news and ideas that effect us.
But we don‚Äôt believe it.
The need for considered, reflective, long-form journalism has never been greater, and for almost 20 years, that‚Äôs what The Monthly has offered, from some of our finest writers.
 
That kind of quality writing costs money, and requires the support of our readers.
Your subscription to The Monthly allows us to be the home for the best, most considered, most substantial perspectives on the state of the world.
It‚Äôs Australia‚Äôs only current affairs magazine, an indispensable home for cultural commentary, criticism and reviews, and home to personal and reflective essays that celebrate and elevate our humanity.

Aunque siempre hay lugar para alguna que otra agradable sorpresa, la t√≥nica general en la industria actual, centr√°ndonos en todo momento en los grandes estudios norteamericanos, invita a pensar en una sequ√≠a creativa en la que plantillas y f√≥rmulas dominan el grueso de producciones. Pero dentro de este desolador y nada estimulante desierto, una ‚Äîcada vez menos‚Äî peque√±a compa√±√≠a como A24 se ha ganado a pulso la etiqueta de oasis f√≠lmico. Desde sus inicios, la productora de la Gran Manzana nos ha brindado piezas de la talla de 'Under the Skin', 'Ex-Machina', 'Lady Bird' o 'Hereditary', destacando entre su cat√°logo del a√±o 2017 una brutal 'Good Time' que puso en la candelero el nombre de los hermanos Safdie, reafirm√°ndoles como un d√∫o de cineastas tan brillantes como √∫nicos en cuanto a sello autoral respecta tras haber enamorado al p√∫blico indie con su 'Heaven Knows Why'. Con 'Diamantes en bruto', Ben y Joshua han llevado un paso m√°s all√° la propuesta de la cinta protagonizada por Robert Pattinson en un ejercicio de estilo descomunal, tan arriesgado como jugarse una final de conferencia con un triple en el √∫ltimo segundo. 135 minutos de pura adrenalina sin cortar encabezada por un Adam Sandler gigantesco que ya tiene un hueco reservado en mi top con las mejores pel√≠culas de un 2020 que acaba de empezar. Si algo hace tan grande al ‚Äîbuen‚Äî cine, es su capacidad para generar sensaciones genuinas y extra√±amente org√°nicas en el respetable. Desde su paso por el Festival de Telluride, han sido muchas las voces que han reivindicado 'Diamantes en bruto' como lo m√°s parecido a un ataque de ansiedad cinematogr√°fico a lo que podamos enfrentarnos; algo que puedo corroborar despu√©s de haber pasado dos horas con las palmas de las manos empapadas de sudor y respirando a bocanadas. Esta reacci√≥n a lo acontecido en pantalla es posible, en parte, gracias al endiablado ritmo que han insuflado Los Safdie a su violenta odisea neoyorquina. Tras una breve secuencia introductoria y una transici√≥n imposible, el detonante no tarda en aparecer, desencadenando una aut√©ntica marat√≥n entre rascacielos y suburbios ante la que es complicado no terminar exhausto. 'Diamantes en bruto' posee un magnetismo impensable para tratarse de un filme que te golpea una y otra vez sin ning√∫n tipo de piedad a cada rev√©s que sufre su protagonista. Una deliciosa tortura que impide apartar la mirada, filmada con un nervio pr√≥ximo al caos ordenado ‚Äîlas conversaciones son antol√≥gicas‚Äî, capaz de sacar de sus casillas al espectador m√°s templado, y narrada en un crescendo constante, de esos que te hacen apretar la mand√≠bula y rechinar los dientes inconscientemente. El dominio de la c√°mara y la maestr√≠a en la puesta en escena de los Safdie se ven enriquecidos por un tratamiento formal casi temerario. Rodado en un 35mm dominado por el grano y las texturas m√°s crudas, el largometraje a√≠sla a su protagonista y le oprime contra los escenarios de la jungla de asfalto en la que intenta sobrevivir, combinando zooms, focales largas y movimientos de seguimiento imposibles en una apuesta visual que va mucho m√°s all√° de su esp√≠ritu ochentero. Ha quedado claro que, formal y narrativamente, 'Diamantes en bruto' es un aut√©ntico prodigio; pero a√∫n queda una bala en la rec√°mara, con nombre y apellido, para terminar de volarnos la cabeza por completo. Esta no es otra que un Adam Sandler libre y desatado que nos regala la mejor interpretaci√≥n de su carrera, perilla en ristre, y enfundado en una abrigo de cuero que grita 2012 ‚Äîa√±o en que se ambienta la pel√≠cula‚Äî a los cuatro vientos. 'Diamantes en bruto' toma todo lo que hizo grande a 'Good Time' y lo eleva a la en√©sima potencia con una salvaje representaci√≥n de la conjunci√≥n latina "lupus est homo homini" que, desgraciadamente, el p√∫blico espa√±ol no podr√° disfrutar en todo su esplendor ‚Äîverla en pantalla grande, adem√°s de un privilegio, es una experiencia impagable‚Äî. Por suerte, el buen cine sigue si√©ndolo independientemente del tama√±o de la superficie sobre la que se proyecte.

Los hermanos Safdie han mostrado una mano notablemente audaz al momento de dirigir sus cortometrajes y pel√≠culas. Desde la feroz readaptaci√≥n del cl√°sico infantil Le ballon rouge (1966) en The Black Balloon (2012), pasando por el agudo retrato de adicci√≥n a la hero√≠na en Heaven Knows What (2014), hasta llegar a la exploraci√≥n del frenes√≠ y la desesperaci√≥n en Good Time (2017), Josh y Benny Safdie redefinen la urbanidad neoyorquina en t√©rminos distintos a los de maestros como Martin Scorsese o Sidney Lumet. Su visi√≥n, m√°s √°gil pero tambi√©n m√°s c√≠nica, filma la urbe como un asfixiante laberinto de concreto y cristal, que en el caso de su m√°s reciente largometraje, Diamantes en bruto, encierra lo sagrado y lo profano en una vitrina de joyer√≠a. Adam Sandler interpreta a Howard Ratner, un joyero neoyorquino que constantemente busca aumentar sus ganancias a trav√©s de empe√±os, subastas y apuestas arriesgadas y cuantiosas en el basquetbol. En medio del acoso de usureros, el rechazo de su esposa (Idina Menzel) y de su familia y la inestable relaci√≥n con su joven amante (Julia Fox, extraordinaria), Howard recibe desde minas africanas una extra√±a opalina incrustada de gemas que capturan la atenci√≥n del c√©lebre basquetbolista Kevin Garnett, de quien depender√° la √∫ltima apuesta de Howard, la m√°s audaz de todas. La pel√≠cula inicia con la extracci√≥n de la opalina en una mina et√≠ope, cuyas resplandecientes gemas son exploradas por la c√°mara antes de transformarse en la colonoscopia de Howard. Los Safdie comienzan su fren√©tico relato con la misma audacia que habr√° de llegar hasta el final de sus poco m√°s de dos horas de duraci√≥n. El vigor de su estilo, prodigiosamente refinado en Good Time, parece venir de los cl√°sicos de Cannon Films ‚Äìcomo 52 Pick-Up (1986)‚Äì e incluso el estupendo score de Daniel Lopatin parece evocar ese esp√≠ritu constantemente, tan sucio e inmoral como atrayente y adictivo. Uncut Gems, su t√≠tulo en ingl√©s, podr√≠a parecer a primera vista una pel√≠cula sobre los peligros que rodean a la codicia, pero apunta a un lugar muy diferente: la necesidad de ganar y de creer que el destino se puede controlar a trav√©s de una apuesta. Si la apuesta se gana, es posible adelantarse al designio divino y llegar a un punto casi org√°smico, pero si se pierde, siempre existe la oportunidad de volver a intentarlo. Eso es lo que nos hace identificarnos con √©l irremediablemente: la incapacidad de detener nuestra propia espiral hacia abajo y dejar de apostarle a nuestra propia tragedia. La peor decisi√≥n es la de desear ‚Äúganar‚Äù, quiz√° por ello, no dejamos de tomarla.
