The hollowness of materialism is on full display in the Safdie brothers‚Äô anxiety-inducing Uncut Gems. Frenetic jeweler and gambling addict Howard Ratner (Adam Sandler) incessantly prowls for the next big score, wheeling and dealing in order to keep afloat even as his mounting debts get him dangled from a window by his ankles or locked in the trunk of his car at his kid‚Äôs school pageant. He‚Äôs driven by his own insatiability, unable to fill the hole inside himself no matter how hard he tries, making the brazen, impulse-driven huckster a walking allegory for the unsustainability of late capitalism‚Äîhe can‚Äôt possibly keep all the saucers spinning forever.  While some people are paralyzed by fear and others are fueled by it, fear rarely enters the equation with Howard. He‚Äôs all id and kinetic energy, a bull in a china shop who just so happens to own a jewelry store in NYC‚Äôs Diamond District. Even when his long-shot scheme to acquire a rare black opal‚Äîa kaleidoscopic stone that looks magical even in the rough‚Äîis about to pay off, the object of his desire isn‚Äôt in his hand for more than a few minutes before he‚Äôs loaning it to a famous customer, Celtics star Kevin Garnett (himself), who believes the rock possesses mystical powers that will bestow good fortune upon him as he plays in the 2012 Eastern Conference semifinals. As collateral, Howard takes possession of Garnett‚Äôs 2008 NBA championship ring. He promptly pawns it (temporarily, in his mind) in order to secure the funds to place a bet on Garnett‚Äôs opal-enhanced performance.  As one might expect, Howard‚Äôs personal life is a mess. His marriage to Dinah (Idina Menzel) is a fa√ßade for the benefit of the kids that‚Äôs nevertheless still in its death throes. His girlfriend and employee, Julia (Julia Fox), will seemingly do anything for him, but still can‚Äôt help but stick her hand down the pants of The Weeknd (himself) at a high-profile party. Howard‚Äôs kids, spoiled as they are with lavish luxuries, barely know him and expect little from him since he can‚Äôt even manage to make it through a full school performance without getting hauled off by thugs working for his loan-shark brother-in-law, Arno (Eric Bogosian). And despite his hubris and volatile temperament, Howard is still rife with self-loathing, which compels him to perpetually seek the temporary relief of fleeting pleasures and the not-so-cheap thrill of going all-in with his feverish pursuit of that elusive life-changing payday. On the surface, Adam Sandler‚Äôs portrayal of Howard appears as the polar opposite of the only other spellbinding dramatic performance on Sandler‚Äôs r√©sum√©, the milquetoast novelty-company owner Barry Egan in 2002‚Äôs Punch-Drunk Love. And yet, though Barry may have been painfully repressed and Howard is brash to his detriment, both march through their respective films driven by a singular focus, with Barry fixated on scoring a lifetime of free airline miles from a Healthy Choice promotion loophole and Howard expecting a mammoth payday either through the auction of his giant opal or from its good-luck charm properties leading to his winning an unlikely NBA parlay bet. The Safdie brothers frantic pacing is more jarring than Paul Thomas Anderson‚Äôs approach in Punch-Drunk Love, and Sandler‚Äôs respective characters trend in opposite directions, with Barry grasping at serendipity and Howard barreling headlong into peril. But Sandler‚Äôs Janus-faced portrayal of these two characters nevertheless taps into the same well of desperation that he‚Äôs perhaps uniquely capable of rendering this distinctively onscreen.  Uncut Gems also bears a two-sides-of-the-same-coin resemblance to the Safdie brothers‚Äô acclaimed 2017 film Good Time. There, the directing duo showcased the humanity behind scrappy criminals near the bottom rungs of income inequality, whereas this latest film illustrates the soulless (if largely legal) excess that‚Äôs inherent to rubbing shoulders with those closer to the top. And yet, despite his frenzied efforts, Howard remains small-time in many ways, hawking tacky jewel-encrusted Furby necklaces and goading a family member (Judd Hirsch) to falsely drive up the bids on the black opal at auction. The Safdies don‚Äôt offer a cautionary tale, glorification of greed or in-depth character study, but rather a stark, turbulent and mesmerizing ride-along with one man‚Äôs futile navigation of late capitalism‚Äôs darker and more fickle realms in pursuit of a windfall that always seems just over the horizon.

Retired NBA star Kevin Garnett (left) plays himself in 2012, doing business with jeweler Howard Ratner (Adam Sandler, right, with Lakeith Stanfield as a business associate) in ‚ÄúUncut Gems.‚Äù To round out the top five such films I‚Äôve ever seen, I‚Äôm adding Josh and Benny Safdie‚Äôs kinetic, electric, pulse-quickening, harrowing and brutally intense ‚ÄúUncut Gems,‚Äù one of the most authentic deep-dives into the world of the gambling addict ever put on film. Adam Sandler‚Äôs performance as a New York jeweler with a variety of voracious appetites, who has spent most of his adult life trying to beat the bookies (spoiler alert ‚Äî you‚Äôre never going to beat the bookies in the long run), ranks right up there the work of Steve McQueen in ‚ÄúThe Cincinnati Kid,‚Äù Edward Norton and Matt Damon in ‚ÄúRounders,‚Äù George Segal and Elliott Gould in ‚ÄúCalifornia Split‚Äù and James Caan in ‚ÄúThe Gambler.‚Äù ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù is part psychological thriller, part black comedy, part thriller and part dysfunctional extended family drama ‚Äî and it clicks on all those cylinders. It has the urgent look and jagged style of early Martin Scorsese films such as ‚ÄúMean Streets.‚Äù (In fact, Scorsese is one of the producers of this film.) It is the story of a man who is in a constant state of high anxiety. Lurking around every corner of his life is the very real possibility he‚Äôll be caught having an affair, get beaten up by a bookie‚Äôs thugs or mess up a business deal ‚Äî or maybe he‚Äôll just collapse on the spot, with the cause of death being Overall Degenerate Lifestyle. ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù is set in the recent past of 2012, in New York City. Sandler‚Äôs Howard Ratner is a hulking, goateed, leather-jacketed, bling-wearing jeweler who makes no bones about who he is ‚Äî a hustler through and through. Whether Howard is behind the counter at his store (which has the atmosphere of a chop shop combined with a high-end flea market) hawking a gaudy chain with a hideously glittering Furby, trying to smooth things over with his wife Dinah (Idina Menzel) OR his mistress Julia (Julia Fox), ditching a couple of menacing tough guys or selling a story to the bookie who says time is running out and Howard better come through with the cash, this guy is always on the run in one form or another. The precise time period is an integral part of the story, allowing the retired basketball great Kevin Garnett to play the 2012 version of Kevin Garnett, a star power forward with the Boston Celtics. Garnett, who went straight from Farragut Career Academy High School on the West Side of Chicago to the NBA draft, was one of the most imposing figures the game ever saw; he‚Äôs also kind of ‚Ä¶ out there. Playing a heightened version of himself, Garnett is nothing short of sensational. It‚Äôs one of the best pieces of real acting by an athlete in recent movie history. You see, there‚Äôs this uncut gem of a stone studded with black opals, newly arrived from Ethiopia. Howard thinks it could be worth maybe a million dollars when he puts it up for auction in a few days. But when Garnett and entourage visit Howard‚Äôs store while the Celtics are in town to take on the Knicks, Garnett is instantly mesmerized by the opal and asks if he can borrow it for a few days. He‚Äôll even let Howard hang on to his NBA championship ring as collateral. Garnett goes on to have a monster game, and he truly believes it‚Äôs because the opal has magic powers. He‚Äôs going to hang onto the opal just a little while longer. Howard, who‚Äôs just as bonkers as Garnett and is increasingly powerless to stop his life from spiraling out of control, makes a huge bet contingent on the Celtics winning ‚Äî AND Garnett scoring points by the bushelful and grabbing a ton of rebounds.  The Safdie brothers are big proponents of the IN YOUR FACE school of filmmaking. One gets the feeling they‚Äôd be almost be disappointed if a few people didn‚Äôt walk out of their movies. In ‚ÄúUncut Gems,‚Äù their camera plunges into the depths of a diamond mine ‚Äî and the depths of a man‚Äôs colonoscopy. The dialogue often overlaps, with two or more people talking over one another, like over-caffeinated characters in a Robert Altman film. Things get ugly in more ways than one. As played with raw, ferocious intensity by Sandler, Howard is not without his charms and charisma, but he never asks us to like him. He doesn‚Äôt really even ask that of his wife, his three children or the girlfriend he claims to love. He even understands why his bookie (who also happens to be a member of his extended family) might just have to kill him. This is Howard‚Äôs world. If you can‚Äôt keep up or you can‚Äôt bear to see him going down, then get out of the way. He‚Äôs not asking anyone‚Äôs permission to do the things he does.

It is not unusual for Adam Sandler to play annoying characters. Starting with Billy Madison and through Jack and Jill, Sandler specializes in people who get under the skin of everyone around them, only to have the audience pulling for them by the end. Uncut Gems, the dark thriller from the Safdie Brothers, takes that formula and deepens it with an unpleasant, irresponsible Sandler character. He plays Howard Ratner, a jewelry dealer, and he‚Äôs the sort of guy who is so irritating that it is a relief when others say that to his face. Somehow the film is watchable despite all that, thanks to a staggering command of tone, dense plotting, and Sandler‚Äôs inherent charm. Howard is a degenerate gambler. His own bookies almost refuse to take the bets he makes because he has no self-preservation or good sense. Howard wants to bet on the 2012 NBA Finals and he has some insider information: Kevin Garnett plays himself, and after visiting Howard‚Äôs store, he lets the NBA star borrow a unique, priceless jewel. The stone might give Garnett some unknowable advantage, and Garnett gives Howard his NBA championship ring as collateral. He immediately pawns the ring, using that money to make his bets, all while he owes thousands to other collectors all over town. He juggles all this while maintaining some veneer of a family life, and making time with his live-in mistress. Josh and Benny Safdie enjoy celebrating cinema‚Äôs capacity to make us uncomfortable. Their last film, Good Time, a crime thriller where Robert Pattinson plays an incompetent bank robber who undergoes history‚Äôs most idiotic crime spree, was hard to watch‚ÄîPattinson‚Äôs character kept exploiting vulnerable people, whether they were inebriated, mentally ill, underage, or did not speak English. But in Uncut Gems, Howard is not fooling anyone: Every character knows he is full of shit, and the question is just how much of his scheming they will tolerate. Aside from the dense plot, Uncut Gems has an impeccable grasp on mood and atmosphere. There is a bravura sequence where Garnett and his entourage visit Howard‚Äôs showroom, and they get stuck between two security doors. They are effectively locked in a cage, while Howard is busy juggling two phone calls. All this unfolds while Howard‚Äôs security buzzer keeps going off. The cumulative effect is so dizzying that it becomes comical. There are slower sequences, like when Howard hides in his mistress‚Äô apartment to surprise her, but even those have an uneasy energy to them. The Safdies suggest Howard‚Äôs existence, while unsustainable, is like some elevated form of living where every moment is an adrenaline rush.¬† To Do This Week is your twice-weekly email roundup of arts and cultural events. It‚Äôs the perfect way to know what‚Äôs going on, and subscribing is a great way to support us.¬† We don't have one. Readers like you keep our work free for everyone to read. If you think that it's important to have high quality local reporting we hope you'll support our work with a monthly contribution.
Love or hate Sandler's degnerate gambler/jeweler, his compulsions are so widespread your own eyes get compelled to stay glued to the screen.

Uncut Gems is a total knockout ‚Äî both in that it‚Äôs a wallop of a film and may inspire a well-deserved nap due to exhaustion shortly after the end credits roll. An epic convergence of nail-biting tension and powerhouse performances, the 2012-set thriller from brothers Benny and Josh Safdie (Good Time) features a career-best turn from Adam Sandler, who‚Äôs brilliant in uncharted territory that nevertheless feels like an apt fit for his talents. The Sandman stars as New York City jeweler Howard Ratner, a compulsive sports gambler up to his diamond-encrusted Furbys in debt. When his loan sharks all come calling at once, Howard concocts grand schemes and new elaborate bets to turn his fortunes around, apparently unsatisfied with the inherent danger of his already fraught situation. If his financial interests weren‚Äôt troublesome enough, Howard‚Äôs also a wreck on the personal front. On the brink of divorce with his wife Dinah (Idina Menzel), he keeps an elaborate apartment for his gorgeous mistress/employee Julia (Julia Fox, magnetic in her feature film debut) ‚Äî all part of a wild juggling act that‚Äôs a miracle to behold. Thanks in large part to the unified efforts of Darius Khondji‚Äôs gorgeous yet borderline intrusive cinematography, Ronald Bronstein‚Äôs and Benny Safdie‚Äôs razor-sharp editing and Daniel Lopatin‚Äôs unsettling score ‚Äî all under the Safdies‚Äô masterful direction ‚Äî Uncut Gems maintains a propulsive pace, yielding thick suspense as Howard awaits the outcomes of gambles that are anything but sure things. At the heart of our antihero‚Äôs quest for success is the titular illegally-obtained rock, speckled with rare black opals, that he‚Äôs sure will net him big bucks at auction ‚Äî plans that naturally don‚Äôt go as intended. Complicating matters and further stoking the dollar signs in Howard‚Äôs eyes is none other than basketball legend Kevin Garnett (excellent as, well, himself), who, following a phenomenal piece of editing when he touches the stone and has a trippy vision of monumental moments from his life, becomes convinced that he needs the stone to prevail in the 2012 NBA Eastern Conference semifinals. In the wake of this terrific build-up, and with everything on the line, Uncut Gems culminates in an extended climax so simple yet genius that it‚Äôs a wonder the scenario hasn‚Äôt been utilized before on film. Sandler‚Äôs dark comedic presence keeps the energy high without plunging too deeply into the abyss too early on, but the cinematic victory primarily belongs to the Safdies, who‚Äôve improved significantly as filmmakers since their previous effort.

Adam Sandler is having a pretty good year in 2019. He‚Äôs made a triumphant return to Saturday Night Live as host, and he reteamed with Jennifer Aniston for the actually fairly watchable Murder Mystery on Netflix. With Uncut Gems, Sandler joins forces with directors Benny and Josh Safdie, makers of the excellent Robert Pattinson vehicle Good Time, and delivers the kind of dramatic performance‚Äîthat being fully committed and thoroughly proficient‚Äîhe‚Äôs hinted at in the past with strong efforts in Punch-Drunk Love and The Meyerowitz Stories. As Howard Ratner, a New York City jewelry store owner and gambling addict, Sandler catapults himself into the upper echelon of today‚Äôs fine actors‚Äînot bad for the creative force behind Grown Ups 2. It‚Äôs 2012, and Howard has built up healthy gambling debts with a bunch of criminals, including relative Arno (Eric Bogosian), who doesn‚Äôt give a shit that they are related. He‚Äôs owed money, and Howard will suffer greatly if he doesn‚Äôt deliver. Howard‚Äôs solution is to obtain a black opal straight from Ethiopia, one that can be worth upwards of $1 million. That opal could free him of all debt and set him on the path to prosperity, especially because NBA star Kevin Garnett‚Äîyes, that‚Äôs Garnett playing himself‚Äîis ready to give him all kinds of money because he thinks the stone has powers. Simply selling the stone at auction and solving his problems would be too easy for Howard, who Sandler portrays as a hyped-up, out-of-his-mind kook who screws up every chance he can get. Whether it‚Äôs his store, or his soon to be gone wife (Idina Menzel), or his well-meaning mistress (Julia Fox), Howard is completely incapable of doing the right thing. Sandler‚Äôs comedic abilities come into play because Howard is so messed up it‚Äôs often funny, and Sandler constantly mines the humor in that darkness. But, in the end, Sandler isn‚Äôt in this for laughs, and Howard winds up being a complete character study, a sad man who doesn‚Äôt know when to quit‚Äîa man addicted to chaos. This is one of those roles that, quite simply, couldn‚Äôt have been played better by anybody else. Sandler was always the one the Safdies had in mind when they were writing the script and, while it took a couple of tries, they finally got their man and delivered a masterpiece. The film doesn‚Äôt just thrive on performances; it‚Äôs bursting with style and originality in its overall approach. The Safdies adopt a visual and sound style that makes Howard‚Äôs crazed adventure a swirling trip. It‚Äôs edited with the sort of electricity that keeps you riveted, with psychedelic trips inside opals, and even Howard‚Äôs colon, to boot. Apart from being one of the year‚Äôs best films, it‚Äôs also one of its most original. So what the hell is going on with the awards so far in 2019? After the National Board of Review named Sandler its best actor, he got snubbed for both a Golden Globe and a Screen Actors Guild Award. (The critics guild I belong to, the Las Vegas Film Critics Society, recently named him Best Actor.) Sandler more than deserves his first Oscar nomination here. His work stands alongside DiCaprio‚Äôs in Once Upon a Time ‚Ä¶ in Hollywood and Driver‚Äôs in Marriage Story as the year‚Äôs best. So how will Sandler top this work? Honestly, I don‚Äôt think he can, but that‚Äôs not a dig on him. Uncut Gems is an example of finding an actor, finding his strengths, and displaying them in a way that amounts to performance perfection. Sandler will do more great things in his career, but it won‚Äôt surprise me if this should amount to his apex. That‚Äôs the highest praise he can get. Dark Waters is an earnest legal drama that spares us lengthy courtroom sequences in favor of in-depth looks at those affected on all sides of the case.
When Adam Sandler decides to bag the fart jokes and really act, few actors are better. This is an intense, almost exhausting drama and one of my favorite movies this year.

Uncut Gems is one of those ‚Äúhis own worst enemy‚Äù capers. You know, the kind of movie where you sit there for two hours watching some doofus constantly trip over his own laces ‚Äî usually figuratively, sometimes literally ‚Äî on the way to a personal epiphany about how all his bad choices and lack of useful self-awareness have led him to whatever unpleasant place they lead him to. These movies can be cringeworthy in the protagonist‚Äôs pathos, either amusingly so or enragingly so. They can engender sympathy or contempt or ‚Äî ideally ‚Äî a combination of the two that nevertheless keeps you on his side. It‚Äôs a tricky mix to get the balance to a place where the audience is walking that fine line with the protagonist, the cockiness leavened by poignancy. You should feel like this guy is probably right to hate himself, but you still want him to win. Gems directors and cowriters (with Ronald Bronstein) Benny and Josh Safdie pulled this high-wire act off beautifully with their 2017 film Good Time, in which Robert Pattinson‚Äôs small-time crook engages in an endless doubling-down on appalling decisions, but does so out of a desperate love for a brother who is unable to care for himself. His brain may be malfunctioning, but his heart is in the right place. Well, no spoilers. We are dragged along here as Howie alternately runs around Manhattan‚Äôs Diamond District and locks himself in his high-security showroom as he attempts to pull off his biggest score yet: turning the large hunk of raw black opal he has imported from Africa into a larger hunk of cash. His plan involves an auction at a fictional luxury house √† la Christie‚Äôs or Sotheby‚Äôs, but before he can get there, he has other, smaller deals to make in an ever escalating series of bad moves: the first involves pawning an item of incredible sentimental and financial value that is not his to pawn. And when his deals go wrong, as they inevitably do, he has to up the ante on himself, hoping for a bigger payoff on the next one in order to keep the juggling act in motion. Uncut Gems is a movie about addiction: Howie is a compulsive gambler ‚Äî sometimes it seems he will risk obscene amounts of money just for the ‚Äúfun‚Äù of it. And the Safdies mine undeniable cinematic tension out of Howie‚Äôs predicament: sometimes it‚Äôs physical tension, because people who have lots of cash around to play with are generally unhappy to be the one getting played, and would like to hurt the player. But often it‚Äôs psychological tension of exactly the sort you‚Äôd imagine: every time Howie digs himself deeper into his hole, you want to scream at the screen for him to just stop it already. Or for someone else to stop him. This kind of tension should be fun, and it would be, if Howie were worth caring about. But Sandler‚Äôs smirking is not endearing or even vaguely interesting ‚Äî except, perhaps, to those who are already fans of Sandler‚Äôs typical antics. To me, they are a turd not polishable by the Safdies‚Äô indie cred, and as Uncut Gems lumbers to its finale ‚Äî at two hours and 15 minutes, it takes too long to get there ‚Äî I knew that there were only two ways Howie‚Äôs exploits could end: either well, in which case he would get to celebrate his triumph, or badly, in which case the movie would get to lament him as a tragic figure. Either would end up infuriating me. And I was correct in this.

Since this is the last column of the year, and honestly, I have no idea if I‚Äôll be able to continue this into another year, I‚Äôm going to change things up a little. I‚Äôm not even sure if anyone is reading anything I write about repertory or limited releases anyway, so we‚Äôll see how I feel about continuing to write all that stuff for free. Wilson-Cairns, which I feel is being overlooked in favor of the technicality of the film, maybe since there are so many stretches without dialogue. Don‚Äôt let that fool you. It takes a great deal of research and description in a screenplay to lead to a movie this good, and the writing that forms the backbone of Mendes‚Äô latest and greatest should not be ignored. 1917is easily one of the year‚Äôs best film, and though it only opens in New York and L.A. on Christmas Day, it will be nationwide on January 10. I also reviewed Rian Johnson‚Äôs comedic whodunnit right here, so I don‚Äôt have a ton more to say about it, but I‚Äôm so happy that it‚Äôs continued to do well since opening over Thanksgiving. If you haven‚Äôt seen it and want a fun couple hours at the movies, Johnson‚Äôs movie can provide that, but it‚Äôs also quite a brilliant twist on the ensemble whodunnit that I‚Äôve generally been a fan of as a kid, and the movie definitely stands up to repeat viewings. I also highly recommend Jay Roach‚Äôs ‚Äúworkplace drama,‚Äù which is about the Fox News sex scandals, mainly surrounding the news corp‚Äôs founder Roger Ailes, as played by John Lithgow. The movie stars Charlize Theron as Megyn Kelly, Nicole Kidman as Gretchen Carlson and Margot Robbie as ‚ÄúKayla Pospisil,‚Äù as a composite character, the story following the three FOX News employees as they navigate the difficult Venn Diagram of politics and sexuality (or sexualization). Most of the events take place around the 2016 Presidential Election and Donald Trump‚Äôs grilling by Kelly about his statements about women, something that backfires for the anchor. At the same time, Carlson is moved to an afternoon slot, and she decides to fight back against Aisles‚Äô demotion (and her subsequent firing) by getting lawyers and accusing Aisles of sexual harassment. As we learn from Robbie‚Äôs character, Aisles gets up to much worse, and I loved what her character brought to the mix, particularly her relationship with Kate McKinnon‚Äôs character. I‚Äôm thinking the movie hasn‚Äôt gotten nearly as much traction with critics because it‚Äôs written and directed by men, in the former case, Charles Randolph, the Oscar-winning writer of The Big Short, but we have to give some credit to the amazing female cast assembled and what they were able to bring to the material to make the film far less dreary than it might have been despite the yucky nature of the Fox News world. I also think that attention should be paid to John Lithgow‚Äôs performance as Ailes, which is a lot more than a good make-up job. Lithgow is such a nice person so for him to play such an oily, slimy character so well makes me think he shouldn‚Äôt be overlooked in the awards conversation. This is now playing in about 1,500 theaters across the country, and hopefully, it will be in even more over the coming weeks. Sort of related to Bombshell¬†in that it explores women‚Äôs issues from a very different standpoint, that of Louisa May Alcott‚Äôs classic piece of coming-of-age literature set post-Civil War. Greta Gerwig ably tackles far more difficult material for her second feature as a filmmaker, proving that Lady Bird¬†was no fluke. It reunites Gerwig with that film‚Äôs Oscar-nominated star, Saoirse Ronan, playing Jo March, the writer who is trying to make her way in life and through her career as a writer. ¬†I‚Äôm not a huge fan of the source material but Gerwig and Ronan have created such a marvelous bundle of joy in this film that follows the journey of the four March girls, but does so in a non-linear way that forces to pay close attention. Ronan is wonderful, as always, but I was equally and maybe even more impressed by Florence Pugh, who plays the super-dramatic Amy in a way that makes her far more convincing as the younger and older versions of her character than some of the other young actresses. ¬†I think Emma Watson as Meg might be somewhat the weak link of the movie but she isn‚Äôt terrible and I did enjoy some of her scenes. Gerwig‚Äôs movie is rounded out by wonderful performances from the likes of Laura Dern, Timoth√©e Chalamet (fantastic as Theodore Lawrence), Chris Cooper, Tracy Letts and others. ¬†Actually, I really loved all of the interactions between Chalamet, Ronan and Pugh, three fantastic actors who I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll continue to see more great things from over the next few decades. I haven‚Äôt seen enough of the adaptations of Alcott‚Äôs book to really know how this stands up, but it‚Äôs the first time I really was interested in these characters and their story, and that‚Äôs quite an achievement. Although Warner Bros‚Äô JUST MERCY (see below) is getting a ton more attention and marketing, personally I preferred Chinonye Chukwu‚Äôs CLEMENCY (NEON), which premiered at Sundance way back in March but just had a much more lasting impact. It stars Alfre Woodard as a prison warden where the pressures of death row executions have started to take a toll on her personal life, especially with the impending execution of Aldis Hodge‚Äôs Death Row inmate, who claims his innocence. This is a really tough drama to watch at times, but with such amazing performances by Woodard and Hodge that it pulls you in and keeps you riveted to what might happen next. I‚Äôm a little bummed that Chukwu isn‚Äôt getting more attention for her brilliant work writing and directing the film vs. other films like the recent Queen and Slim. ¬†She‚Äôs a great filmmaker and I can‚Äôt wait to see her next film, A Taste of Power. I‚Äôm not as big a fan of the works of Ben and Josh Safdie as many of my fellow critics are, but this crime-comedy (of sorts?) starring Adam Sandler, helped make me see their crazy mode of filmmaking in a new way. While I recommend this with reservations, I do think that Sandler‚Äôs role in the movie as Howard Ratner, a New York jeweler merchant to the stars, could help the Safdies break out to a new audience as they certainly seemed to have refined their mode of filmmaking with Uncut Gems, and the mix of characters and situations really make the movie something unlike anything else you‚Äôre likely to see this year. ¬†The gist of the story is that Howard gets his hands on a valuable gem from Africa and that seems to change his luck as a chronic gambler where everything seems to be going right for him‚Ä¶ until it doesn‚Äôt. ¬†Much of the story involves him trying to get the rock back from basketball player evin Garnett (played by himself) who borrows the valuable gem and then won‚Äôt give it back. ¬†All-in-all, it‚Äôs a pretty entertaining film with an absolutely amazing last act that will expand nationwide on Christmas Day. In case you don‚Äôt want to go out in the cold this week, you can also stay home and watch some of the great films now on Netflix. While I assume you‚Äôve already seen The Irishman¬†and Marriage Story, I hope you‚Äôll also check out this wonderful two-hander written by ¬†Anthony McCarten (Darkest Hour), which explores the relationship between Pope Benedict (Anthony Hopkins) and his successor Pope Francis (Jonathan Pryce), as they try to get along even though they don‚Äôt see eye-to-eye on how the Catholic Church should be won. I was a little surprised how much I enjoyed this movie, but it reminded of a little-seen 2016 movie called The Journey, a two-hander starring Timothy Spall and Colm Meaney as two sides of the war in Northern Ireland trying to come to an accord while driving to the airport from talks that have fallen apart. ¬†I‚Äôve long been a fan of Pryce but playing the Argentine cardinal who would become Pope is a fantastic role that allows him to show so much more depth as an actor, but we also learn a lot about Pope Francis‚Äô past and the regrets he has about his involvement with the government‚Äôs anti-religious actions. Hopkins is also great, and for a movie that‚Äôs mainly two men talking, it‚Äôs perfectly captivating. Although it‚Äôs been out for a while now and has already been losing theaters, I also recommend checking out Marielle Heller‚Äôs It‚Äôs a Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood, starring Tom Hanks as Mr. Rogers, if it‚Äôs still playing anywhere near you, because it‚Äôs a really wonderful story about a journalist whose spotlight of Mr. Rogers turned into a way that he can find redemption in his own family issues. As mentioned in my write-up of Clemency above, I wasn‚Äôt nearly as crazy about Destin Daniel Cretton‚Äôs JUST MERCY (Warner Bros.), which is a different movie with similar elements, this one starring Michael B. Jordon as Bryan Stevenson, a young civil rights attorney who is trying to free a wrongly-convicted Death Row inmate, played by Jamie Foxx. Cretton‚Äôs good luck charm Brie Larson (they first teamed for Short Term 12) is also in the movie, but I don‚Äôt feel she‚Äôs nearly as good, and there was just something about the movie that really didn‚Äôt click with me. Even so, it will also be nationwide on January 10 and maybe I‚Äôll try to give it another chance before then.  I was semi-excited about Donnie Yen‚Äôs return in the title role of Wilson Yip‚Äôs grand finale, IP MAN 4: THE FINALE (Go USA Films), which has the martial arts master who trained Bruce Lee (and whose first name, I only just realized, is ‚ÄúMan‚Äù) comes to San Francisco in the late ‚Äò60s to back up his pupil‚Äôs desire to teach non-Chinese martial arts. Along the way, he gets into issues with the local martial arts masters as well as the Marines, who believe that Japanese judo is the only proper martial art. As with some of the other movies in the series, this one is mainly good for Yen‚Äôs performance and his martial arts scenes, although Kwok-Kwan Chan is also excellent as Bruce Lee in one particularly good fight scene, and there are a few others as well. My main issue with this, as with may martial arts film from China, is that the American actors are written terribly and the performances they‚Äôre giving (particularly by regular offender Scott Adkns) are just terrible. It‚Äôs a classic case of over-villifying the non-Asian characters to the point of them being a joke, and there are few surprises about who is going to win in most fights. It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve seen the other chapters, and martial arts fans will probably like parts of this, but it‚Äôs not a particularly good movie when all is said and done. A movie I liked quite a bit more is Fran√ßois Girard‚Äôs historical drama THE SONG OF NAMES (Sony Pictures Classics), produced by Robert Lantos (Barney‚Äôs Version), another terrific Canadian film that deals with Jewish issues. It stars Tim Roth as Martin Simmonds, a young British man whose family took in a Polish Jew named Dovidl, who was also a violin virtuoso, to live with them just before the start of WWII. The night of Dovidl‚Äôs anticipated 1951 live concert debut in London, he vanishes, and years later, Martin, starts to track down his old friend to find what happened to him. It‚Äôs a pretty amazing movie, partially due to Roth‚Äôs performance, but also the two young actors playing Martin and Dovidl, since so much happens in the past. Like much of Sony Classics‚Äô output, this will probably appeal more towards older audiences, but it‚Äôs another original story set during the period of the Holocaust that puts its own spin on the times with the musical element, which plays such a large part in the film. (Clive Owen plays the older Dovidl, but it‚Äôs a fairly small role compared to the others.) I‚Äôm very excited that The 21st Annual Animation Show of Shows (ACME Filmworks)is returning to the Quad Cinema on Christmas Day, and while I was hoping to write something more extended about this, I just haven‚Äôt had the time. There‚Äôs an amazing line-up of films from a lot of different countries including Germany, Switzerland, Russia, Belgium and more, but there‚Äôs also a couple doc shorts about the filmmakers among the films. The Czech Republic film Daughter¬†was recently included on the Oscar shortlist for animated shorts, but otherwise, it‚Äôs a fairly strange mix of films, including the very disturbing Kids. I haven‚Äôt seen Wayman Boone‚Äôs horror film Apparition¬†(Vertical Entertainment), starring Mena Suvari and Kevin Pollak, but apparently, it‚Äôs another horror movie involving an APP that connects to the user to the dead. It‚Äôll open this Friday. A few other things on Netflix over the next couple weeks including John Mulaney and the Sack Lunch Bunch special, which looks like more quirky fun from one of my favorite stand-up comics. That opens on Christmas Eve i.e. today, while a couple new series begin on Netflix on New Year‚Äôs Day, The Messiah(starring the wonderful Michelle Monaghan) and Spinning Out.  I decided to take a much-needed break from the repertory stuff this week, but we‚Äôll see what happens with that going into the New Year, and I‚Äôll have my annual Top 25 to share with you all next week!

Okay, we can officially retire Punch Drunk Love as the oft-cited example of Adam Sandler‚Äôs competence as an actor. Sandler is a kinetic force in the Safdie Brothers‚Äô wild, breakneck thriller Uncut Gems, a film that races at such a pace, continually raising the stakes to absurd degrees it might be too much for the weak of heart. And Sandler‚Äôs the guy thriving in the middle of this raging hurricane, delivering the best performance of his career and making it look damned easy. The Gambler for a new generation, that classic film doesn‚Äôt conjure up a fraction of the desperation and¬†anxiety created by Uncut Gems.. Set in the New York City diamond district, Sandler plays Howard Ratner, a guy who‚Ä¶frankly, it‚Äôs really tough to feel sorry for. Howard is that guy you know who just can‚Äôt keep his mouth shut, he‚Äôs always in some kind of trouble, usually of his own making. Howard may own a jewelry shop, one frequented by NBA stars such as Kevin Garnett, but he‚Äôs really just another guy up to his eyeballs in debt. There‚Äôs scarcely a person in Howard‚Äôs chaotic existence that he isn‚Äôt in hock to, and something‚Äôs got to give. Claustrophobic cinematography crams us into Howard‚Äôs shrinking world, and we walk practically in his footsteps through every moment, every risk, every inexcusable high-risk decision.¬† EVERY decision Howard makes is terrible, by the way, as if he‚Äôs trying to make his situation worse. It can be exhausting, even when Howard seems to have found a way out, because we quickly learn there is no such thing for a guy like him. His ticket out of this seemingly endless cycle of vigs, threats, hustles, and side-bets is a rare black opal diamond acquired from Ethiopia, literally dug out of the earth by poor miners in a sequence that looks like the beginning of an Indiana Jones movie. Supposedly worth millions, Howard intends to auction the jewel off and strike it rich. But of course, nothing is so simple. Garnett enters the shop, thanks to Howard‚Äôs associate Demany (Lakeith Stanfield), and becomes entranced by the diamond‚Äôs mystical qualities. He asks to borrow it, just for one game, believing it to be an inspiration. Howard‚Ä¶well, he‚Äôs just not a smart guy. He makes the absolute worst decision possible, especially with guy around every corner who want their money and are willing to do terrible things to get it. As if the streets weren‚Äôt punishing enough, the Safdies go even deeper and darker when exploring Howard‚Äôs personal life. Even at home Howard is living one big con. His marriage to Dinah (Idina Menzel) has been on the rocks for ages, and although they‚Äôve agreed to divorce they‚Äôve yet to let the kids know. Even Howard‚Äôs brother-in-law Arno (played by a menacing Eric Bogosian) is after him, and with a pair of mobbed-up goons at his side, too.¬† And of course, Howard has a side-chick (Julia Fox) as if the pressure wasn‚Äôt mounting quite enough. All of this ratchets up in ways that are both hysterically pathetic. When a school function for Howard‚Äôs daughter ends with him naked and locked inside of a car trunk, you think that would be rock bottom‚Ä¶even though you know deep inside that it isn‚Äôt. A trailblazing examination of greed at its most toxic, Uncut Gems is also about a guy who is willing to do anything to carve out his slice of the American Dream. Howard risks everything to make his mark, and at times you can almost respect him for always betting on himself to come out on top. Set to an electric soundtrack and the Safdies‚Äô dizzying direction, this is a film that will test your mettle like few others do. Somehow more intense than Good Time and twice as haywire, Uncut Gems reveals the Safdies to be filmmakers who revel in the anarchy they cause, and invite others¬†to revel in it right along with them.

A critical assessment of the merits of a subject, such as art, film, music, television, food and literature. Reviews are based on the writer‚Äôs informed/expert opinion.  An early match cut signals the mayhem to come in ‚ÄúUncut Gems,‚Äù the latest filmic face punch from Josh and Benny Safdie: a shiny black opal morphs into a throbbing colon. It‚Äôs also a tip to the character played by Adam Sandler, whom you could call a real orifice. He‚Äôs Howard Ratner, a jeweller in the New York City of 2012 who seems to spend more time getting into trouble than he does selling precious stones. That‚Äôs his colon on the screen, in all its gross glory. A fidgety cat with dyed hair and goatee, diamond ear studs and a bad gambling habit, Howard has a knack for pissing off everybody he meets, which includes his soon-to-be-ex-wife Dinah (Idina Menzel), his mistress/employee Julia (Julia Fox) and the mobsters to whom he‚Äôs deep in debt, to the tune of more than $100,000. Good thing the glass doors of Howard‚Äôs Manhattan office are bulletproof ‚Äî although the buzzer that opens them frequently malfunctions, giving the film additional jolts of comedy and drama, depending on who‚Äôs attempting to gain access. Howard figures he can solve all his problems by auctioning off that hunk of uncut opal, which he managed to smuggle out of Ethiopia (inside a dead fish) and which he swears is worth millions. He‚Äôs both lucky and unlucky to have NBA star Kevin Garnett (who plays himself) as a client. Garnett takes a shine to the rock, setting in motion a series of events that aren‚Äôt going to make Howard‚Äôs life any easier, to say the least. Watching it all go south, with restless camerawork similar to the Safdies‚Äô previous film ‚ÄúGood Time,‚Äù might just fray the last functioning nerve you have in your body. That‚Äôs a compliment ‚Äî and so is the observation that this is the best character Sandler has ever played. He‚Äôs so much better as an orifice than as a moron. Anyone can read Conversations, but to contribute, you should be a registered Torstar account holder. If you do not yet have a Torstar account, you can create one now (it is free).

The title of ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù could stand in for the whole thing: This is one rough, glittering beast of a movie. It also refers to a valuable black opal, its facets mostly encased in rock, that in the film‚Äôs opening scene we see being dug out of the side of a mountain by two Ethiopian miners while their bosses are distracted by a grisly pit accident. That opal will spend the rest of ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù tantalizingly out of reach of one Howard Ratner (Adam Sandler), a Manhattan diamond dealer, gambling addict, part-time husband, and full-time hustler. Because Howard never stops moving, neither does the movie, and the effect is both exhausting and electrifying. Watching this latest bulletin from the Safdie brothers, Benny and Josh, is like grabbing hold of a high-voltage line: It doesn‚Äôt feel that great, but good luck letting go. Howard‚Äôs in hock to a shady brother-in-law named Arno (Eric Bogosian) to the tune of 100 large; Arno has called in some out-of-town muscle in the form of two Boston thugs, one of whom (Keith Williams Richards) has a face like the back of a Chelsea cement truck and the eyes of a dead fish. ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù follows Howard over the course of a few days as he stays a step ahead of his pursuers while trying to arrange the deal that will set him up for life (he says): the sale of that opal at auction for possibly a million dollars. Howard has a worst enemy, and it‚Äôs himself ‚Äî that‚Äôs the comedy of ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù and its tragedy as well, especially for those unlucky enough to come into his orbit. He has a wife out in the suburbs, Dinah, who‚Äôs pretty much done with him, and the pure annihilation Idina Menzel can pack into a throwaway glare is marvelous to behold. Aside from one son (Jonathan Aranbayev) who still worships him ‚Äî which won‚Äôt last the movie ‚Äî his kids have thrown in the towel, too. Why wouldn‚Äôt they, when his daughter‚Äôs school play is interrupted by having to get dad out of his car trunk, where he‚Äôs been dumped, naked, by his creditors? But the opal, the opal ‚Äî that will make everything right, or so Howard promises his mistress, Julia (Julia Fox), who also works in his brightly lit second-floor retail shop on 47th Street. It‚Äôs what he brags to his elderly father-in-law (Judd Hirsch) at a crowded family seder where the Ten Plagues get a full airing. It‚Äôs how he hustles Kevin Garnett, the Celtics star played engagingly by Kevin Garnett, into believing the opal has some kind of lucky mojo. (The movie takes place in 2012, during the semi-finals between the Celtics and the 76ers.) When Garnett insists on borrowing the jewel ‚Äî leaving his emerald-encrusted championship ring as collateral ‚Äî the stage is set for the movie‚Äôs high-tension Rube Goldberg treadmill, with Howard running as fast as he can while getting nowhere. Somehow there‚Äôs a nightclub fight with The Weeknd (playing himself, too); somehow there‚Äôs money passed along a ledge, a visit to Mohegan Sun, and a last-ditch gamble that any sane person would run from in terror. The movie starts in high gear and stays there, the synthesized squalls of the score by Oneohtrix Point Never chasing the hero every step of the way. They should have defibrillator stations posted in the lobby. Let me be very clear about Adam Sandler in this movie: He is brilliant. The actor makes his living off idiot comedies and every seven years or so deigns to take on a dramatic role, just to remind us he can. ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù is of a higher order than that. Sandler inhabits this character fully and without vanity, working Howard‚Äôs ready smile and desperate eyes and needling, never-ending sales pitch into a devastating portrait of a lesser shark, the kind who‚Äôs always late for the kill. It‚Äôs not an actorly performance; it‚Äôs instinctual, unerring ‚Äî bone-deep. ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù is a New York movie the way directors like Martin Scorsese and Abel Ferrara used to make: street-level, profane, mesmerized by awful men. Ferrara has tended to romanticize such figures, but Scorsese never did, and the Safdies stick to that tradition. (Not coincidentally, Scorsese lends his name to ‚ÄúUncut Gems‚Äù as executive producer.) The brothers grew up in New York before studying film at BU; their father worked in the diamond district; the movie feels set in known territory. Their earlier movies (‚ÄúGood Time,‚Äù ‚ÄúHeaven Knows What‚Äù) have been terrific. This one‚Äôs the best yet, if hardly for the faint of heart. The Safdies don‚Äôt judge Howard Ratner, or celebrate him, or condemn him. They just let us watch from a safe distance, marveling at all the balls he keeps in the air and knowing it‚Äôs only a matter of time before they fall. Directed by Benny and Josh Safdie. Written by Benny Safdie, Josh Safdie, and Ronald Bronstein. Adam Sandler, Kevin Garnett, Julia Fox, Idina Menzel, Eric Bogosian, Lakeith Stanfield. At Kendall Square. 135 minutes. R (pervasive strong language, violence, some sexual content, brief drug use).

It‚Äôs possible that tension is the hardest element of a movie for a filmmaker to create and maintain as they see fit. While there are multiple rules and proven formulas for injecting humor in a scene, eliciting pathos in a dramatic sequence, or even thrilling audiences with spectacle, developing a sense of tension takes a deft hand that is more about a sense of what is right and anticipating audience reactions than it is about following any patterns or previous molds. The Safdie Brothers‚Äô UNCUT GEMS is an exceptional model that deploys, builds, and preserves a sense of tension from the opening shot to the closing credits. Powered by incredible performances from Adam Sandler, Kevin Garnett, Julia Fox, LaKeith Stanfield, and Keith Williams Richards, this anxiety-inducing maelstrom of a terrible person constantly making everything worse is a brilliant character study, an engaging story of various lowlifes, and one of the best films of 2019. Howard Ratner (Sandler), is a man constantly on the hustle. A gift for gab and charm to spare, Ratner is a degenerate egotist who works in the jewelry district of New York City jeweler. His gambling issues spread beyond just NBA bets, including grifts with his friend Demany (Stanfield), a worrisome relationship balancing act with his wife (Idina Menzel), and his mistress/employee (Fox), and a precious uncut stone bought on the black market from Africa. As his bookies become more insistent that he pays up, and his schemes unravel at alarming rates, NBA superstar Kevin Garnett walks through the door and suggests a new angle for Ratner to take. The Safdies‚Äô GOOD TIME was a bold and intense cinematic experience filled with random twists, slick style, and its own share of constantly escalating problems for the characters. That film was somewhat hampered by the fact that too many people that cross paths with the protagonist are essentially innocent folks, or don‚Äôt recognize how the extent to his self-destructive and manipulative nature. UNCUT GEMS improves on that previous work by surrounding the asshole protagonist with equally scheming and despicable types, while also having a number of people calling Ratner out on being just the worst. This tweak makes audiences feel less like being unwitting accomplices to deplorable actions while also making it easier to simultaneously hate and root for Ratner. Viewers can hate him because he‚Äôs just an inept con man who barely stays afloat while constantly lying to everyone around him; but they can also root for him because it‚Äôs clear that he‚Äôs not alone in his awful ways in the corrupt world he is frantically moving through. Sandler is incredible as Howard Ratner proving that, when he has good material and cares about a project, he can actually churn out a fantastic performance. The character has to be a papier-m√¢ch√© Mephistopheles, a person that tries to exude confidence and control but is clearly a moron who is losing is grip on everything; but Ratner also has to be pathetic to elicit some humor and also some pathos as this is just a guy trying his best and can‚Äôt figure anything out, especially that he is his own worst enemy. It‚Äôs a layered performance that is grating, aggressive, subtle, and powerful all at different times and is the pin that holds this story together. The supporting turns are also impressively engaging. Garnett is great as this version of himself who is a weird and superstitious dude that also likes playing the heel. The Safdies originally wrote this film many years ago, prior even to GOOD TIME, and so the NBA player in question was constantly changing depending on schedules and acting abilities ‚Äî but clearly it was fated to be Garnett because he is incredibly mesmerizing on screen and a great pseudo-foil to Ratner. Julia Fox does great work as ‚ÄúJulia,‚Äù who is a bit of a cipher ‚Äî it‚Äôs hard to tell exactly what she is thinking or her true motivations. Is she another sloppy con artist like Ratner? Is she na√Øve? Is she a fourth-dimensional manipulator? There‚Äôs enough in the script and in Fox‚Äôs acting that will leave audiences unsure for the vast majority of the film, which only ratchets up that tension. UNCUT GEMS is full of adrenaline but not in a rushed or frenetic way. Instead it‚Äôs more akin to a shark that has to keep moving or else it will die. That doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs fast-paced‚Äîwhile it moves along at a clip, there are plenty of quiet scenes and comic interludes between moments of Ratner‚Äôs continuous downward spiral. But it constantly maintains that street hustle vibe of someone who is always moving, always spitting game, trying to sell their knockoffs or scam someone rube who just happens to be on the wrong sidewalk, with an eye always looking for that elusive ‚Äúbig score.‚Äù Ratner is a New York Jewish version of FARGO‚Äôs Jerry Lundegaard¬†‚Äî constantly trying various doomed schemes who has seemingly chosen the easy path of tracking in lies, despite being pretty terrible at it. That cursed sense of every worsening conditions brings to mind other gritty character affairs with tightening nooses in films like THE GETAWAY and MACHINE GUN MCCAIN. The Safdies know exactly how long to dwell on terrible situations, when to allow a release with a joke or a different tangent, when to inject hope, and when to double down on the ever widening shitstorm that seems to be engulfing Ratner and everyone in his vicinity. UNCUT GEMS an amazing experience from gifted filmmakers who deftly appreciate what audiences need and expect, choosing to subvert those when necessary to intensify the tension and leave viewers as entertained as they are racked with panic.
